review_content: Aroma; scents from black caramel, roasted malts, grass, some syrup. Look; fawn head, on coffee black body. Taste; flavours from floury black caramel, roasted malts, figs, dates, fudges, some black syrup, and finishes somewhat malted. Feel; okay body and co². Overall; it reminds me of schwartzshbeer. [8-10cl from can, T@ O'Reilly Men, thanx to Mulligan, Flanagan, Donovan, Branigan, Sullivan, Cunningham, Gach Éireannach, and Saint Patrick.]

The aroma is malts, bread and a little fig/date. Pours almost black with big foamy tan head, mostly diminishing and excellent lacing. The taste is blah a tad bitter. The body is light, the texture watery with a slight creaminess, the carbonation is average. A large brew beer, has something but doesn't get there.

Темный Лагер от всемирно известной Ирландской компании. Марка говорит сама за себя, но вот Темный (Черный) Лагер - это что то новое. Впервые (по моим данным) пиво было выпущено в 2011 году для продажи в Англии. Ирландские пиво любы увидели этот продукт только летом 2012 года на прилавках в Ирландии.

Пиво черного цвета, цвет можно сравнить с Coca Cola. Пена не густая, быстро падает. Солодовый запах. Выделить что то сложно. Вкус солодовый, очень водянистый. Неудачный вкус от Гиннесса. Но попробовать стоитю

A lighter/thinner version of the old skool Guinness Extra Stout.  More like a regular black lager versus a traditional Schwarz, which may have a bit more caramel and creaminess to it.  I prefer Guinness's Stouts to this (especially their new Foreign Extra)...but this is a decent lighter change of pace dark beer.
Bottle.  Pours a black colour with a tight beige head,  the aroma is roasted malt with a hint of bread,  the taste is medium bitterness and with a watery bitter finish.

Jesus, remember this shite! Was out about a decade or so ago. Probably not long on the heels of Breo. Think it was basically just Harp but with a little black patent malt thrown into the mix for colour. Another failed attempt from Guinness. Not dissimilar to all the shit they are flooding the market with nowadays. After 250+ years, you'd think these guys would be the best of the best. Guess it just goes to show what happens when you sit on your hands for two centuries and then someone else makes something that actually tastes good. Panic sets in, big time!

I have friends who LOVE this beer, and I have tried several times to drink it but just don’t see what all the fuss is about. I have yet to be able to finish a full glass. By the time I get near the bottom the taste is just horrible,
Bottle. It poured black with an off-white head that quickly dissipated. Roasted malt aroma with notes of lightly scorched coffee. The mouthfeel is watery/thin. Ok lager, but wish it had more flavor.

Pours an average size frothy head and has a very dark brown colour. Aromas of light roasted malts, earthy and herbal type hops. Flavours are all fairly mild composed of coffee, light roasted malts, mild spices. Slightly watery, but not too much. Some spices are apparent in the finish. No bitterness at all. Medium bodied, average retention. Has a pretty smooth mouthfeel. A Guinness beer made for warmer times. Goes down real well. Still prefer the stout but would drink this again.
A black lager is a summertime delight for a big stout fan like myself. This is light and smooth with that signature Guinness yeast. Thin, smashable body with a light roast flavor. Ireland beer baby!
Great beer for any occasion. I always start my night off with one of these.

I was surprised how well I enjoyed this. It was toasty and very dark but refreshing on an autumn day. There are certainly better examples to be had of the style, but for the price this is not bad. It is something a little bit different.

Chestnut brown color with a head of light tan bubbles that diminishes to a thin lid. Caramel scent, akin to kitchen bouquet. Really not much of a sniff. Flavors of ashes and a hint of dark malts. Light acidity in the linger. Really not much as far a flavor. A quenching dark lager? 7/11

A weird one this. It doesn’t taste like a lager, it tastes like a watered down Guinness. Malt, cocoa and light coffee on the palate, maybe a bit of a black tea notes as well. Much thinner consistency as well. Not sure who it was aimed, young drinkers, session drinkers who find Guinness too heavy? It’s an experiment which didn’t pay off for Guinness, but I would try it again.

Tried in Northern Ireland when it was first launched.

330 ml bottle from Liquor Depot, served in yet another thrift shop find, a Stella Artois chalice. (It replaces one that I unfortunately broke before it had a chance to hold more than just two or three beers. A shame, as it had no wear showing on the gold rim and logo.) Pours an opaque near-black shade with a cocoa-hued head that leaves fine lace webbing. Doughy, roasted grains and malts, earthy and herbal noble hops, plus grass, and hints of straw, cocoa, and coffee on the nose. Overall flavor is very whole-wheat bready - similar to a brown ale, but without ale yeast’s spiciness, it lacks a little in dimension, but it’s appealingly smooth-drinking all the same. Creamy and chewy as well. Definitely a well-done dark lager, with plenty of body and a very welcome, sessionable ABV of 4.5%.

Opaque black hue with a beige head that settles rapidly. Lager driven aroma with notes of malt and honey, but with the addition of roast. Extremely thin bodied. Malt, hay, honey and roast flavour. Lacks robustness as expected, but quite refreshing.

Bottle pour into nonic pint glass from Downtown Discount Beverage. Aroma is purple grape/dark fruits, noble hops. Appearance is dark brown--almost opaque--with small off-white head that fades quickly. Trace lacing. Taste is strong rich malts with dark fruit and mild noble hop bitter balance. Palate is light-to-medium bodied with thin texture and tongue-stinging lively carbonation with crisp finish. Overall, more fruity than a traditional Schwarzbier but good nonetheless.
Bottle. Tastes like raisins, dark roasted malt, some dark chocolate, and burnt coffee. Light/medium body and carbonation. Smells like dark roasted malt, raisins, and burnt coffee.

Funny how Guinness has these other products that I never think about.... and occasionally bump into running around the planet.This has a decent foamy head and black body, sorta the non-creamy version of the "proper" Guiness product if’n you will. Macro barley on the nose, nothing more, nothing less, adequate. Flavour is faint roasted barley. Really watery palate. Not sure what the point is, it’s sort of like a watered down stout. Odd thing, not awful, but I wouldn’t buy it again.
11.2 oz. bottle. Pours black/cola colored. Minimal tan head. Aroma of roasted malts and sweetness. Taste was weak coffee and roasted malts.
Bottle. Pretty dark brown pour with a decent tan head. Aroma is roasty chocolate, simple but not bad. Flavour is thin and metallic, not much going on at all.

33cl bottle at home. Pours a black colour with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, bread, dark malt. Taste is moderate sweet, medium bitter with a moderate dry finish. Notes of roasted malt, bread, dark malt. Texture is watery, light bodied with moderate carbonation
On tap in Annapolis, MD. Dark malty body with medium head. Nose is coffee, chocolate, barley. Taste similar of coffee, some chocolate. Then turns bitter. Okay.
FTA. This was available all over Europe. I had this in TLL, Frankfurt and UK. A ok schwarzbier, but nothing more. Black - check, lagerlike - check.
Old rate. This is not the worst thing in the wold, tates like a roastier lager version of guinness. Still prefer the original with the ball can.
Pours jet black with tan hesd that stays. No lacing. Smell is malts, alcohol, cereal. Taste is semi sweet. Boring.

12oz bottle into a Corsendonk badged stemmed tulip on 19th May 2015. As the name suggests this is a black bodied lager, the head a slowly dispersing lightly tanned head. Mild malt nose, the taste also malts to the fore in the flavouring. Nothing special, nothing wrong with it: but not really for me, I prefer my beers less carbonated and less lager-like overall.
Bottle. Creamy roasty aroma and taste. Smooth, easy drinking, and better than I thought it would be.

Bottle from the COOP... Clear dark walnut brew, foamy light khaki head sticks around for a bit... Nose shows washed out dark malt and little else. Flavor is dry bitter maltiness with background dry toast... No hops to speak off... watery.. Won’t ever buy again.

Pours black, of course. Has a nice tan head and some lacing. The head retains pretty well...Aroma, the main thing I notice is coffee. There’s some roasted malt in there. But it’s more like drinking bottom of the pot coffee....Taste, still coffee, maybe some cocoa. The roasted malt comes through a little more in taste than in nose....Mouthfeel, yeah, it’s pretty smooth, it’s well balanced. Semi dry. It’s pretty heavy....Overall, it’s not bad. It reminds me of a regular Guinesss, I guess you could call it a Guinness Light. It’s not what I would call sessionable.
Old rating. Pass. Dark clear body. Roast, char, and a strange metallic/sulfuric presence. Almost no reason to drink this.

Creamy, coffee and light chocolate in both aroma and flavor. Weak bitterness which fills the upper part of the mouth briefly. Okay beer with your meal. But enjoy it, you can not. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass.
Aroma- Dark roasted malt
Appearance- Has a dark coffee color with a tan colored head.
Taste- Strong flavor of roasted malt with a bitter flavor, nice
Palate- A medium bodied brew with moderate carbonation, has a creamy to slight oily texture that goes well with the flavor.
Overall- A nice Euro Dark Lager, I would order this if I saw it on a bar list.

This black lager is a heavy consistency but not appealing with food. It is, however, a beer is be okay drinking without any food. I'd still rank it only a bit above average overall.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Dark color with tan head and some lacing.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle into pint glass. Pours a black colour with a very little off white head. Aroma is light roast and a touch of sulfur. Taste is roasted malts and a sulfury sweetness. I am assuming from the yeast. Decent black lager.

Bottle: Dark brown body with a light-khaki cap that fades quickly. Metallic aroma with toasted grains, roasted barley, a hint of dark malt, maybe some coffee? Kind of vague & light. Flavor is crisp, notes of roasted malt, mild ash, grains, & again some of that metallic twinge towards the back-end. Over carbonated. Pass.

Pours blank with a chocolate foam. Molasses aroma. Sweet molasses malty flavor immediately on the tongue. The sweetness grows with each taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

Poured a good head that quickly died off. Dark brown in colour. Tastes of toasted malt and caramel. Very sweet. Mouth feel is thin. Like most Guinness beers, it’s become a pale imitation of a real dark Lager. Kind of boring.

330ml bottle served in a Guinness pint just out of the fridge:

This one pours an aqueous opaque black robe letting loose a frothy maple head with a rough structure showing moderate retention. You can see some rough lacing here and there but it quickly dissipates.

The nose is somewhat sweet but you mostly get the roasted barley expressing notes of grounded coffee beans. The roasted aspect of the nose is well executed.

On the tongue, you get a diluted version of the original stout. The barley is less present and the brew has less body so that’s kind of a downer. It has however a moderate bitterness that stays a while on the back of the palate.

Overall this brew is an ok version of what a black lager should be with the barley of a stout trying to make its way to your palate. Good but not great.

Look: pours dark. With a light brown head.
Smell: slight bitter taste. Roasted malt. 
Taste: roasted malt. Bready. 
Feel: thin mouth feel. Medium carbonation.
Overall: ok beer. Nice flavor. 
First drank: hime 12/1/14

16oz can. Dark ruby black with tan head. Aroma of roast/toast and wet sneakers. Light body, not to bad at first- roasted barley, toasted nuts. As it warms up and you trudge through it ounce by ounce it becomes less and less drinkable. It’s not horrendous, but most schwartzbiers I’ve had have been better. Finish is light roast.

Tasted on 11/21/14 from a capped 12oz bottle purchased at the grocery store in a mixed sixer. Pours nearly black dark brown with a thick beige head that slowly recedes to average lace. The nose is malty dark bread with a bit of a marshmallow note. The flavor is about the same with just a touch of bitter char. The body is light with lively, fizzy carbonation, and a short malty dark bread finish.
I absolutely LOVE this beer! Great Guinness taste. Just discovered it and can’t believe I am so late in trying it. Great beer!

Loin derrière la classique Guiness en cannette, cette "black lager" est un peu anonyme. D’un sombre surmonté d’un col quasi inexistant, cette bière quand même sympa a quelques discrètes notes de café et de malt brûlé avec une finale minimement amère et sucrée.

Bottle Oct 2014. Absolutely foul. Tried this a few years ago, and hated it. Nothing's changed. The burnt taste actually turns my stomach. Only beer on the planet that I'd rather pour out than drink.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
malty, slight roasty aroma. pitch black with little head. taste is slightly malty, slightly roasty. balanced, smooth finish

11.2 oz. bottle from Cash Wise in Williston. Appearance: half finger light khaki head, black color, opaque, good lacing. Aroma: earthy molasses, light licorice, light roasted grain. Palate: full body, soft carbonation, light bitter and dry finish, oily texture. Taste: sweet malt into a light roasted grain astringency, aftertaste is light licorice that lasts. Overall, surprisingly good, nothing amazing or standout about this beer, but smooth tastes and palate.
Plain dark lager with a slight roasted malt flavor. Very clean finish. A simple lager.

Dark, semi-opaque body with ample bubbly tan head. Aromas of grass, corn, roasted barley (in that order). Flavour is weak compared to its stoutly homologue but still bears some likeness. Weak, dilute MF. I’d rename this "Budweiser, Dark Roast".

"light but pleasant aroma and flavor of roasted malts, caramel and/or mollasses. refreshing dark beer...nicely done. i was not a fan of Guinness til the foreighn extra got there (that beer is awesome) but this one is quite pleasant even though light. nothing that’ll blow you away, but quite nice all-around."

Pours dark brown, almost black, with very little foam. The aroma is a little bit of charcoal, a little bit of coffee, and average lager notes. The flavor is slightly sweet and rich, but the after-taste is godawful. Medicinal. A little astringent. I won’t have this again.
From a bottle. Black pour with a very thin head. Sweet malt aroma. Sweet on the palette and all around just ok. Not a fan just kind of blah.

Black beer? More like, blah beer. The appearance is nice, but that?s it. You really have to reach for the Nutty, malty, roasty nose. Taste is of weak malt flavourings, bread crumbs and old coffee. Balanced but boring. Guinness, don?t quit your day job.

Muito creme. Castanho e denso. Líquido negro e opaco.
Aroma adocicado e alcoólico. Intensidade média para baixa. Um pouco de canela. Muito bom.
Pouco densa. Típico sabor de café torrado. Um pouco picante. Muito mais suave que a Guinness original. Bastante amarga.
A nice looking black beer with a beige head. Odd aroma. Like artificial dry stale light roasted malt. Flavor is similar. No real quality character. Does not offer much.

Guinness Black Lager has a pretty thick, spongy, beige head, which dies away rather quickly, a very dark brown appearance, with some brown highlights around the edges where the light hits it, and faint lacing left behind. The aroma is of mild, dark bread crust with a trace of sweetness. Taste is of dark, but not burnt, malt, sweetness, bread, and a rounding hop bitterness at the end. Mouthfeel is light to medium, and Guinness Black Lager finishes smooth and highly drinkable. RJT
Black pour with a thin head. Sweet malt aroma. Sweet on the palette and all around really. Slight hints of roasted malt flavour.

What a waste of ingredients.

Dark beer with a nice foamy head. That’s the only positive, looks. It has a slightly nutty flavour with hints of coffee.However, it tastes awful. It’s nothing short of a horror. Something that should never have been created.
Taken from notes. Dark brown w/ thick foamy head. Very smooth with a nutty flavor and hints of coffee. Less bitter than the stout and overall a very sessionable beer.
Virtually flavorless beer save some lightly sweet, fruity notes and a little bit of toast. Spritzy, watery and low on everything.
Aroma of roasted coffee, taste is roasted coffee, malty, mild alcohol, easy drinker.

Pretty good taste. Like it!
Pretty good taste. Like it!
Pretty good taste. Like it!
Pretty good taste. Like it!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rich, earthy brown pour. Trademark tan foamy Guinness head. Love the light toastiness of this! Very eady drinking.
Black as the name implies. Roasty aroma, a little coffee. Flavor, same with a little chocolate. Good drinkability, okay.

Clearish but black colour and a white head. Muted aroma, some roast, some barley and a hint of something sweet. Medium bodied palate, watery mid and a slightly sweet and roasted barley flavour. regrettable purchase. I only bought this one because of a world cup matchup. Italia!!!!
Pours a nice black color with off-white head. Roasted malt and just a bit of coffee on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with more roasted malt notes.

Transfer from BA review on 4-7-12 - 
Poured from bottle into pint glass

Appearance- Pours a nice dark brown nearly black color with a lighter tan head. The head faded quite fast giving way to a very light lacing.

Smell – The smell is largely of lighter roasted malts and is of light coffee and chocolate notes. 

Taste – The taste is of roasted malts and is of light coffee and chocolate notes. These start out a little more on the sweeter side and bitter more as the taste advances. But the flavor is overall very consistent throughout.

Mouthfeel – The mouthfeel is a bit on the lighter side with a medium level of carbonation. The carbonation is quite appropriate and complements the beer quite well, but the mouthfeel leaves something to be desired as it could use some more thickness.

Overall - Nothing too spectacular, but not bad. I prefer the original stout, as the lager is a bit more one-dimensional in my opinion.

Bottle: Poured a clear dark color lager with a small off-white foamy head with OK retention. Aroma of lightly toasted malt is mildly pleasant. Taste is also dominated by lightly toasted malt with light dry bitter notes and watery finish. Body is light with OK carbonation. This is a water-down version of Guinness which says a lot about this beer.

Aroma is yeast, ash, fruit, interesting. Pours opaque black with a khaki head. Awesome lacing. Flavor is honestly lacking dark flavor. In a blind taste test it could pass for a light-colored beer. I can’t taste any roasted or dark flavors. Light body, sweet finish. Decent as far as beer in general but for the style not so much.

330ml bottle from LCBO. Toronto, ON. 4.5% alc. / vol. Pours an opaque black colour with a small mocha head. Aroma is grassy, hoppy and some notes of coffee. Well balanced hoppy taste. Light body with low-moderate carbonation.

Rated on 11-02-2011 (Bottle) When poured, this beer has a medium sized fizzy tan head with a short retention, dark brown body, fizzy, fast rising carbonation, and virtually no lacing. The aroma is roasted malt. The flavor is roasted malt and lightly sweet. The mouthfeel is light carbonation and this beer is light bodied. This beer lacks character in the flavor as there is not much to it.

Tall pint can from a "Irish Beer" 8 pack sold at Harris Teeter in Huntersville, NC. Pours a nice black color with a light aroma of mostly malt, coffee and chocolate. Taste is mellow and has an easy finish. Not bad but it could be better.
Pours dark with a mild beige head, the barley comes through in the taste, giving it a similar flavor to that of burnt caramel.
bottle. Hazy blackish with small head. Ashy charred malt. Bland and watery. I don’t like the style much, but this is underwhelming to say the least.

Definitely Tastes like a Guinness. Roasted aroma with same taste and a little bitterness at the end.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Drinking this a day late and it's the wrong damn one. Got it free. I feel like I actually got less out of the deal.

Has the requisite roasty malt nose, and drinks smoothly with a nip of hops, but lacks some of the crispness common to this ’black pils’ style. An easy session beer that would be at home next to virtually any pub grub, Guinness Black Lager is an interesting foray into this often duplicated but rarely perfected style.

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. Dark brown with white wave. Sweet, a little caramel aroma, sweetish taste and very slightly roasty. Light body, a little more fizzy than the Guinness stout.

from a cold tall metal can of it into 1 english pint glass; charred coal and drawn long through the gullets o’.
I’d had this prior and din.dt like it.
do now. do still.

Drunk from 33cl bottle in kilcullen, Ireland. Pleasant enough but no defining features.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I dont really understand what they thought they accomplished with this very below average beer only plus is it goes down good

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. Dark brown with a bit of beige foam. Aroma of malt, caramel, light roastiness, a bit of oxidation and vegetal notes. Sweetish flavor, slightly roasty, with a bit of caramel, toasted bread and a drier and slightly bitter finish. Rather light-bodied.

Black body with a tall, rocky tan head. Aroma is lightly roasted malts, a bit of sweet malts. Thin body. Flavor is light and unpleasant. Light sweetness and dry toasted malt. A bit of bitter roasted malts on the back end. This is a poor attempt at a schwarbier.

Black with a red tint and a thin, white, frothy, disappearing head. Smells of dark dirty barley, feat, caramel extract, and dark malt. Medium thin body. Tastes of flat coke, with barley, caramel, malt extract and dirt. Very processed and blah. It’s not good
Pours black with a small white head. Aroma is light toasted malts. Taste is really lacking. Expecting some big roasted flavours, finding none.

Bottle.

A- Metal, roasty, coffee.

A- Black color, dark liquid, tan head.

T- Licorice, roasted cereal, spiced.

P- Medium body, average texture, medium carbonation, boring finish.

O- Tastes like a Guinness Draught but with an obvious lager feel. Definitely does not look as great as a Guinness but it’s not a bad beer.
Nice toasty aroma. Was hoping more from the body though. Pretty weak with mostly metallic notes. Lager body is fine but there’s just not much flavor
pours a dark black with a small head. the aroma roasted malt, brown sugar. the taste is very similar. not a terrible beer by any means but not the best.
Tastes like Coke with a slight coffee aftertaste. I’m not sure if I drank a beer or a soda. If an alcoholic Coca-Cola was the goal, then they did a great job.
Horrible..tried on a whim, just to see if Guinness has anything left to show..they don’t..
Poured black into a pint glass with a little head but unlike the stout. Almost a burnt barley flavor. Seemed a little thin. Would have this if nothing better is around but that’s about it.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, caramel, bread and notes of coffee.

330 ml bottle purchase at the Hawkesbury LCBO on Decembre 12, 2013. Very dark burgundy, thin head. Aroma of roasted grain, a little coffee. Taste of light grains, dry and, sweet notes of sour fruit, aftertaste of dry coffee. Well it is its weaker cousin and that is not saying much!

Bière noire de 4.5 % d’alcool. On dirait du « coke ». Elle ne possède aucun col au versement. Elle possède un odorat sucré, mais on sent l’aspect commercial. Elle possède un goût salé et sucré à la fois. Il y a un aspect métallique dans le goût. Elle a un goût léger de torréfaction. On goûte bien la céréale (orge). Correcte !

440ml/15floz can from Irish Discovery pack into a Guinness glass; served cold.

Aroma: Pretty neutral. There’s some mild malt, but nothing that really stands out.

Appearance: Barely translucent ruby and brown body with a quickly dissipating, but foamy at first, light brown head.

Taste: Pretty malty, yeah. Decent, but once again, no notable flavors to call out. No chocolate or anything like that. Just roasty barley, and that’s ok.

Palate: Medium body. Carbonation is kind of prickly, but not excessively. Short finish.

Overall: A pretty decent one. I wish there were something in the taste or aroma that would remind me of Guinness draught or stout, because I don’t know if I could have picked this out as a Guinness brew in a blind taste. Decent enough though! Simple and good.
From a bottle. Good dark head and decent lacing. Unremarkable aroma, but smooth drink, not bitter at all, nice lager.
Dark color. Malt, barley, yeast. Very rugged beer. Acidic but not very bitter. Medium body

Poured from a bottle. Medium brown color, slight off white head. No real aroma. Taste is also bland with slight notes of pepper.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Media pinta. De color negro. Engaña, aparenta tener cuerpo pero en el primer trago quedas decepcionado.
Smooth and not too bitter. Might not be suitable for those who like a really strong taste, but I found it quite enjoyable. Paired well with sandwiches.

A light malty aroma, some hints of roasted malt, a little bit sweet. The small fizzy head disappears fast, the body is black. It tasted a little bit malty, quite bitter. The body is light to medium strong and lively.

Black w/little brown @ bottom. 2-3 finger head fades. Leaves little laceing. Smells like Guinness & a BAD lager. Taste:Barley flakes,roastedness, sour(ish), chocolate, & lager taste. It was good but be even better if it had a stout taste over the lager taste but the bottle I had, had a date that passed when I had it but didn’t say if it was best b4 or not. The lager part I found the worst part.

Black lager definitely pours about as dark as any beer could. It mimics a Dunkel or Doppelbock in color thanks to roasted barley that’s been added. While this beer pours with a very large head and fine lacing, there is very weak aroma to it (exhibits small amounts of malt scents). Perhaps not as strong as similar beers in Europe, it does have a fair amount of carbonation, though its taste seemed nondescript. 

The "Black" has a body that falls just short of being medium but drinks easy. It’s unlikely I’d buy this one again if other choices are available but was glad to try this beer that might not be marketed in the US forever. It’s short on taste, but if you don’t like beer it might be the right one for you.

Wat kan ik zeggen er is maar 1 guinness, zeer donker bier niet al te veel smaak 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Refreshing but bland otherwise. Color is s mice coca cola black . Not a bad choice overall

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours an opaque black with a thin unimpressive off white head. Aroma is coffee and cocoa. Taste is sweet roasted malt, with a little coffee and chocolate. Some bitterness after the swallow. OK.

Bouteille de 330 ml achetée chez ANBL (Tracadie, N-B). Arôme: Légère odeur de céréale grillée. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence d’un mince col beige mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de céréale grillée avec une pointe de chocolat et de miel. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une etxture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de céréale grillée en arrière goût. (Rating #5318)
This was lighter than water, and even tasted like water with the tiniest tinge of charcoal and London yeast. Nothing special.

A: Dark Opaque Hue, Passes Very Mild Light, Brown Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Corn, Burnt Wheat

T: Corn, Mild Dark Malts

M: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Mildly Sticky

Overall, it tastes like your typical cheap lager with corn but a mild dark malt flavor, not the worst beer I have ever had.

Noire en apparence, brune à la lumière, elle semble mince et relativement pétillante ; arômes de chocolat, de café, mais surtout de sucre d’orge en nez. Douce et un peu aqueuse en bouche, elle dévoile des saveurs de grains torréfiés, et peu d’autres choses. Plutôt linéaire, elle est cependant plutôt agréable, elle manque seulement d’un peu d’audace et de personnalité. Encore une fois, on n’était pas loin chez Guinness de faire une excellente bière noire, mais c’est toujours le manque de saveur qui cause sa perte.

I guess these are two categories of beer that don’t mesh: guiness (or as I prefer to think of it "meal in a glass" and lager). It sort of ends up being the ’special’ cousin. The dark, sweet maltyness of the guinness is there, but is not really complemented by the lighter mouthfeel and high carbonation of this one. Was slightly better once it warmed up, but overall doesn’t really work. If it ain’t broke........

Bottle sample at a tasting at beerandbeyond shop. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours brown to red clear with a small beige head, aroma is roasted with honey, caramel, chocolate, flavor is slightly bitter with caramel, herbs, light bodied

This lager poured a deep black colour with a nice, big, creamy head. To the nose there are scents of roasted malt, tiny bit of vinegar and cooked veggies? First sip was quite thin with flavours of roasted malt and light smoke. Finish is medium smokey and a faint hop bitterness.
Bottle. Typical lager with malted taste. Roadted malts come through in aftertaste. Go to beer if no craft brew available.
Bottle. Pours black, roasty, toasted aroma. Medium sweet taste. Thin texture and mouthfeel, mild uneventful finish. Sessionable and decent but nothing special.
Not enough roast grain aroma or taste to carry this one. Overall mouthfeel is watery and no lasting palate. Black and more of a lager than a schwarzbier, and hardly worthy of the Guinness name.

Just tried one yesterday...from the bottle. Was hoping it would taste like a malty dunkel...no such luck. Seems like they just took a stout and added malt syrup to it. Weak, watery and bitter. Wouldn’t recommend this to anyone.

Serving: Bottle from Total Wine Sterling. It pours black with a small and fleeting tan head. The nose has a little bit of roasted malt and an odd vegetal note. Thin on the tongue with a slightly tangy, roasted bitterness, a slight burnt note, and a light sweetness. Finishes fairly clean. Pretty meh.

Bottle. Relatively sour aroma with some roast and toast. Clear dark garnet brown under an off white ring. Lactic acid sour flavour with very faint roast and some cinnamon and nutty notes. Light body, moderate carbonation, lingering unpleasantness in the
Smells faintly of malt. Pours a nice guinness black with a nice head. Tastes of smooth generic lager without the corn or rice notes. Smooth watery lager.

faint malty aroma..black stout like appearance with slightly off white head..taste is of a sweeter lager but not very powerful anyway mostly bland..tingly and watery on the palate overall their other products much preferred
Bottle. This is a thin and bland tasting schwartz without the hop bite i expect.
I was greatly disappointed, the only time that Guinness has ever truly disappointed me. It has all of the bitterness of the other varieties of Guinness without any of the other flavors.

Monkeypiss. No idea how it ended up in my fridge. Pours dark brown with thin white head. Scent is chemicals and grain. Scent is slightly sweet. Barely there roasted flavor fades into mild sweetness and weird aftertaste. Overcarbonated to hide the fact it is garbage. Bottle - Source Unknown

Recently added to the Ontario-Quebec market (maybe rest of Canada too). Pours a dark brown colour with a bubbly beige head, decent retention and lots of soapy lacing. Roasted malt aromas with some rusty hops that make it on top with time. This is the same for the taste where the rusty hops become stronger with time. Watery toasted malts with slight burnt bread. Notes of chocolate appears in the nose eventually. Made thin for those who do not like the thicker Guinness stout. An average macro schwarzbier.

11.2 oz bottle. L3028GD001. (Midtown Wine) Nashville, TN.

Black colour with a red hue and a small tan head. 
Sweet malt, toasted bread and brown sugar in the aroma. 
Sweet malt and some darker tones in the flavour. 
Not very good.
Bottle. Taste is fairly tame, especially when compared to a standard Guinness. Perhaps it is unfair to compare the two. Very average lager.

One day, Gemma Aterton will look back at her career and cringe at the idea that she did "Hansel & Gretel". And so will Guinness with this beer. It tastes like a glass of water that has been added with leftover black beer and cigarette butts.

12oz bottle. Poured an opaque black color with a brown, frothy head. Smells of roasted malt and coffee grounds. Sweet, malty flavor initially with bitter roasted finish. Light, watery body, somewhat overcarbonated.
Guinness flavour without the gorgeous creamy palate and deep black look topped with solid froth. Its fine for a lager, like the regular draught, just lighter in body.

Just what the beer world needs: another banal lager. Tried first at toronto beer fest where the guy working the booth said "it wasn’t until they made this that i started liking Guinness products" which probably isn’t the best sign. Happy says its not bad; I say why bother. Meh.

Pours a cola colored medium liquid. Frothy tan head dissipates quickly to a thin lacing. Smells of aluminum. The palate is one of fizzy carbonation, followed by the taste of some malty sweetness. A slight sourness rounds out the taste. Finishes with a slightly bitter aftertaste. I’d buy regular Guinness Stout 10 times out of 10 when considering the brand.
Bottle. Dark brown, almost black with a small sized head. Blah ... muted roast and chocolate. Maybe I did it wrong - I see in the description to enjoy ice cold straight from the bottle ....

Taste lightly tangy/acrid but not sour, some cigarette ash in with faint roast, faint hint of chocolate, relatively dry with low bitterness. Medium-full body. Well, they made this one easy, I’ll take the regular Guinness instead ten times out of ten.
Very dark in color, one could mistake this for a glass of Pepsi! Slight bitter taste of the top with a smooth finish. The aftertaste is a little bitter though. Overall not a bad beer!

Not bad for such a commonly found beer. One of my early favorites, yet is disappointing after experiencing other beers. Very dark color, aroma is lacking but is not offensively skunky, fairly bitter, texture is appealing as well.

Bottle. 
Black color. Tan foam head. Malty. Medium body and soft carbonation. Bitter finish.
Rouge très foncé, presque noir en couleurs, avec un petit collier beige. L’arôme est de malt et de mélasse, le goût est très similaire. Comme un hybride Guinness-Lager.

330 mL Bottle. Dark brown-black body with a frothy beige head that quickly settles to a foamy film. Aroma of sweet and toasted malts, grains, hints of chocolate and treacle, and grassy hops with a sharp floral and corn husk note. Somewhat light on the body but with a bold yet not overwhelming flavor of sweet and toasted malts, black coffee, a sweet malt aftertaste with soupçons of chocolate and treacle, and a peppery hoppy finish such as would be found in a good lager-type beer.

Dark brown pour with a white head. The aroma is chocolate and lightly roasted malt with some sugar notes. The flavor is similar. I get some grainy chocolate notes and roasted malt. Thin, watery mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Bland.

Pours as dark at the stout with an off white head lacking the creamy look of the stout that quickly dissipates .Nose is roasted malt. Palate is medium body with crispness of a lager. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, bitter chocolate. Indeed, ti is the lager version of the stout. 14.9 oz can in an 8 can variety pack.
Bottle @ Home. Pours very dark brown with a small offwhite head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, light chocolate. Thin body, soft carbonation, rather dry finish. 040813

Can. Touch of stale husky grain in the nose, but really, not much there at all. Pours black with ruby highlights and a foamy tan head. Taste lightly tangy/acrid but not sour, some cigarette ash in with faint roast, faint hint of chocolate, relatively dry with low bitterness. Medium-full body. Well, they made this one easy, I’ll take the regular Guinness instead ten times out of ten.
Bottle. Very dark brown with tiny head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and caramel. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, little sweet and a little bitter.
Bottle @ barbecue tasting. Clear very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty and roasted malt. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and roasted light bitter finish. 030813
bottle. Creamt off-white good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Moderate malty and light hoppy aroma. light bitter flavor. Light bitter finish. Oily palate.
33 cl bottle, Mulmur, ON, Canada. Dark brown, cola-like appearance. Roasted malt with faint floral hops. Roasted malt flavour, some chocolate with a nuttiness. Finish has more chocolate.

Dark brown mahogany with an initially foamy but quickly dissipating light tan head. Light salty/minerally sea air and toasted wood aromas. The flavor is so light that there’s really very little there. A hint of char, dark chocolate and cereal malt, and a faint taste of it’s bigger brother. A light molasses sweetness and some balancing bitterness (from hops or malt it’s hard to say). Equally light body. Finishes nicely with what seems like more aftertaste than actual taste. A little too little all around, but not bad and quite refreshing.

330 ml bottle. Thanks P & J.

Pours a black colour with a small foamy head which fades quickly. Aroma of cereal with some burnt characteristics. Watery flavour of roasted malts, very mild bitterness and cereal. Light bodied, thin mouthfeel and low carbonation. A sucky schwarzbier.
Bottle. Dark brown body, creamy head. Coffee tones in aroma. Coffee also in taste, roasted malts too. Medium bitter finish.
Black pour, light nose, mostly malts, coffee, chocolate. Taste is mellow, coffee. Easy finish. About the same as Guinness Draught but definitely not as good as Extra Stout.
12 oz bottle shared by my bro. Thanks Ryan! deep brown with a tan head. light dark malt flavour. quite watery. a waste of time. worst guinness product ive had.
Definitely a lager. Watery and no head. Not sure what I was expecting but I know this is not it.

Meh. Pours black brown with not much head. Aroma is mold roast. Flavor is very thin, slight roasted, not much going on. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had to try this since it comes from the real King of Beers. Don’t know what I was expecting, but this isn’t it. It is moderate at best as a lager and the color really just seems to be an attempt to capitalize on the black reputation. It is not very smooth and lacks any real character.

2 oz sample from Diageo rep. Black pour with a bubbly tan head of little retention. Aroma is overtoasted barley. Mouthfeel clean, medium-high carbonation. Taste is dominated by an almost burnt graininess, the roast malt character isnt tempered by anything but the carbonation. Not worth a repeat or mass distribution.

Not a good sign when the official line from the brewery is "enjoy straight from the bottle". Not even close to the obvious comparison of Kostritzer as far as schwarzbiers go, not awful but not overly satisfying either. Not enough coffee aromas, lack of depth in the palate.

A friend told me about this beer. Like its predecessor, Guinness doesn't seem to know how to make tasty beer. It leaves a hoppy taste in your mouth that lasts. It does not have many notes but still better than standard Guinness, which is a one note beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark, like a Guinness. Aroma sort of smelly like a Guinness and a lager mix. Taste? Well, Guinness and lager mix. It's what it is. Lagers don't rate high, neither does this really. I got a free Guinness bottle opener when I bought it tho! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPad
Pours a dark black with almost no head. Very little carbonation. A little watery, but overall not too bad.

Several bottle samples at the LCBO on WIlson as I explained what the term and style was to the friendly rep they sent out. Its black without much head, or unfortunately much taste either. It’s not up to the style. Better than the stout they serve here.A bit thin and overcarbonated.
Bottle at Guinness Storehouse, Dublin: Very black brew with an taste of roasted malts and at the same time refreshing. Bold move to try something from Thuringia.

4pack at home from Asda, 2011.

Black, fizzy, thin, burnt toast dissolved in water. Poor

Bottle - puts a dark brown/black beer with ruby highlights in your glass - a hard pour makes this look like a guinness - half black foam but there is no long term retention to the cap...demure aroma some light sweetness and roastiness....flavour starts with roasty malts but the hops show up just before the finish which is not really dry but roasty and lightly bitter. This will not displace Kostritzer as a commercial schwarzbier but it decent .

Very excited to try this as I am a recent convert to true Guinness. Sweet caramel aroma, bitter, with burnt cereal taste. No lasting flavour sacrificed for carbonation. I’ll stick to the real Guinness!

330 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a very dark brown with smallish tan head.  Aroma is roasted cereal grains with hints of coffee.  Flavour is burnt cereal grains with light coffee and very faint licorice notes - a little watery.  Body is on the thin side.  Pretty forgettable.

Disappointing as hell, I really expected more from Guiness than this.  I was somewhat excited to try this, but this black lager really just fell kind of flat for me.  Seemingly geared in the advertisements for those who can’t handle real Guinness, this black lager is rather dull.  Aroma is a fainter version of the real thing, light roasty sort of scent.  Appearance is almost like a Guinness but with none of the enticing cascades or obvious richness - simply black beer (but that is what I suppose a black lager is).  Taste is disappointing, dull - makes one wish desperately for a pint of real Guinness.  Over-carbonated, boring, and no lingering aftertaste or satisfaction at all.  Tastes like a sell-out drink designed to appeal to people who don’t like Guinness.
Like I said, it makes one wish for a real pint of the black.  If you’re a fan of the Schwarzbier style, Okanagan Spring’s Brewmaster’s Black is a far better choice if you can get it.

Black with a bit of light that escapes, looks like a porter. Small bubbly off white, beige head. Odd, malty, cereal, dme aroma. Body is thin, and watery, carb is very low, almost flat. Finish is pretty bland, light malts, more dme. Meh, i guess incredibly clod this would be refreshing? Lawn mower beer if you ask me.
The look of Guinness but none of the character, almost a watered down version.   Black with tan head, some roasty notes to it, smooth and creamy feel.   I could drink this on occasion but average.
This beer was nothing special here. More like a watered-down Guinness with light carbonation. Cheers.
Bottle. Pours dark brown/black with a frothy tan head. Aroma of roasted malts and a hint of chocolate. Flavor was very mild with dark roasted malts, grains and a touch of chocolate.
Black in color with an average beige head. Aroma is of roasted malt, coffee, cola. Taste is roasted, toast, cola.
Bottle. The smell is chalk, roast, malt, basic, and ash. The taste is more fruit but mostly the same. The look is black, dark, and cashew colored head.

Ok, but its my least favorite Guinness(by a lot).  Roasty nose and taste up front; but after that, nothing but a pretty average beer.

Bouteille. Cette bière est noire avec une mousse blanche. La texture est mince. On dirait une Guinness Extra Stout coupé avec de l’eau. Un produit inutile car la Guinness est déjà passablement rafraichissante et un produit de plus n’est pas nécessaire.
I MUST have a bad bottle.  This stuff can’t be that bad.  Strong aroma of septic.  Taste of boiled leaves and fermented grass.  borderline drain-pour. Why would Guinness make something this bad?

A - Pours an opaque black body with 1.5 fingers of tan head that sinks into a cap of micro bubbles.

S - Earthy yeast, wet cardboard, copper, sweet toasted grain.

T - Dark malts, grassy hops, light molasses, spicy bite, hints of fruit, raisins, old coffee, finishes dry some spice.

M - Light to medium body, moderate carbonation.

Better than I expected. Easily sessionable. Alot of people will probably hate on this because its from Guinness but it’s actually not too bad for style.

Serving type: bottle

10-18-2011

Expected dark color. Smell pretty decent, sweet malt. The taste is off however. Tastes cheap. It’s almost as if the essence of Guinness was mixed with the essence of rolling rock. If you are a Guinness fan, do yourself a favor and stick with the real thing
Black is appropriate as this beer is dark.  Too dark, with a lack of bubbles/carbonation.  Looks are deceiving as it smells like a light lager.  Bland taste, ok finish.

This seems to be a very good variation of a common lager to me, as other comments say, it’s good alternative to drink a lager. Good aroma and appereance, very dark and apparently, full-bodied. Great taste for a lager, with some notes of coffee, chocolate and a little of caramel, it seems to be more like a light stout, but with a good ending, leaving a nice sensation in the mouth.

Bottle: &nbsp Cola in color, moderate to thin frothy light beige head, dies quickly leaving spotty lacing. &nbsp Soft roasty nose. &nbsp Thats pretty much where anything good stops. &nbsp On the tongue its very shallow, the roasty 

character is barely even toasty. &nbsp Seems thin, finishing with hardly anything. &nbsp This one is very very pale, and very very weak. &nbsp Fairly thin in body and on the tongue. &nbsp Watery backside. &nbsp Nothing off about this 

one, just weak and/or watered down to a point that its rather boring.

330 ml bottle from Broue Ha Ha, served cool in a tulip glass. 



App.:  Deep brown-black with a decent light mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Stark roasted malts, slightly tangy, metallic, lightly earthy,  not great.
  
Palate:  Medium body, moderate carbonation, a bit astringent.
  
Flav.:  British dark-roasted malts, lightly grape-like, a touch tangy, tight; dry with limited bitterness and a rape-like, dark roasted malt finish.



Dark and boring.

11.2 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Dark brown, cola like, tan foamy head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and yeast. Taste quite consistent mostly roasted malts and yeast. Nice and drinkable, good alternative over regular lagers, enjoyable.

I want to start by saying that I am a huge stout fan and I still really loved this beer even if its a lager tribute to one.

It might have a prominent roasted aroma to it, it might not have the most pronounced head, it might not even be that lively on the palate. 

However, this is a smooth easy going beer with plenty of flavor and an interesting take on a lager.

Noire et peu mousseuse. Nez de foin mouillé avec une légère pointe d’anis qu’on ne me reprocherait pas d’avoir halluciné. En bouche les illusions sont confirmées; nous avons davantage affaire à une «lager» qu’à une «black». Le style Schwarzbier qui met davantage la couleur du malt rôti que ses saveurs est aussi confirmé. À l’aveugle, j’aurais probablement mis un gros 5$ sur une lager blonde allemande... et j’aurais perdu mon argent et mon temps.

rootbeer color to it, tan, small head.  smells like roasted malt.  tastes like roasted malt.  not a very big body to it, but pleasant.  I dont like the really dark roasted malt flavor in beer for the most part, no exception here.  but this was ok and tolerable.
330ml brown bottle. Black pour. Small creamy cap. Sweet nose with some roast hints. Taste has mild roast and some metal. Some sweet notes. Roasty and metal aftertaste.

Bottle 330ml.
Pours dark brown with medium beige head. Aroma is of roasted malt. Taste is of roasted malt, yeast. Palate: Ligth body. Somewhat dry. Overall: Bland. Nothing really interesting here. Still drinkable.

De couleur noir très foncé et opaque, cette Guinness est dotée d’une mousse blanche standard. Nez peu houblonné, sucré, avec des notes subtiles de café et de malt grillé. En bouche, le goût amène une réminiscence de Guinness crémeuse, mais c’est plus subtil et moins goûteux. Les flaveurs de tourbe sont absentes. Le goût est léger, comme une lager déguisée en foncée. Goût de rousse, je dirais. Notes caramélisées toutefois très subtiles. Pas mauvais, mais pas extra non plus...

pours clear brown with a quickly diminishing very light beige head, no retention. pale lager aroma with hints of caramel and roastiness, hints of ashes and coconut. earthiness and cheap demerara. some oxidated notes. average carbonation, light body - some texture though, short and almost bland herbal finish. DP.

where to begin black lager sound bad ass as all hell but its a pretty generic light lager smells like hay grass kinda summery out door nice dark not black color pretty standerd small head taste like hay with a little extra something maybe some guinness? something good ? still though better than most generic lager and for that guinness i thank you

Pours a clear dark brown with a brown head.  Aroma is dominated by roasted malts, coffee and a faint sweetness follow.  Taste is good gulp of roasted malts, bitter cocoa, bad coffee and then transitions into a dry finish.  Medium-light body and not much going on in this one with a terribl astringent taste on the finish.

12 oz bottle from Baruni’s in Baden, PA.  A nice addition to the Guinness family and a good alternative if you’re not quite up to drinking a stout.  Wonderful colors and rather smooth on the mouth feel.
Bottle pour - smoky roasted malt goodness here with the Guinness dryness.  A good beer to walk around a bar with.

12oz bottle from winter variety pack poured into lager glass.  Very dark ruby-brown color with off-white head disappearing to just lacing.  Aroma of faint sweet roasty malt ... that’s really it on a few inhales.  Taste is slightly better with the roasty malt standing out, some weak chocolate and coffee notes.  Light body, very carbonated, refreshing.  I guess this is for easy drinking, and it does that okay.

Very unpleasant nose -- corn, cardboard and soap -- all the hallmarks of a cheap, mass produced beer. Taste is rather plain. Not offensive but unremarkable. Thin and gassy, almost has a soda quality to it.

Guinness Black Lager est brassée à basse température à partir d’orge grillé.  C’est bon signe.  Un liquide qui se présente comme un cola.  Sa tête fond pour devenir un simple anneau.  Le nez me semble mince avec ses parfums de pain très grillé et de grains cendrés.  Son goût manque de profondeur avec des malts grillés plutôt effacés.  Son corps n’est pas trop mince.  Le pétillement rend le liquide crémeux.  Sa finale est courte sur une amertume de malts rôtis.  (Date de production: 03/02/13)
Nothing special about this...tastes like a golden lager with a touch of dark malts on the finish. Some sweet fruity and grainy aromas and flavours, otherwise nothing special.

Tastes like skunked Heineken with some food coloring added. It is devoid of body and features an uncomfortably rough bitterness profile. Not recommended, even if being given away.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Not actually too horrible with a nice mild roast and a few bitter notes. The pour looks like a water Guinness with a crap head. Overall, just grab a Guinness instead

330ml bottle. Looks like a thinner Guinness draft, more light got through and the head was lighter and thinner. Smells like half and half stout and lager. Taste is what I would imagine Guinness would taste like as a lager, copper coin and lager hops. Body is creamy for a lager, but still light. Fair bit of carbo. Overall, a drinkable allusion to a stout.

Aroma has the faintest hint of smokiness in there and is dominated by a roasty malt, but is not too aromatic at all. Colour is a nice super deep brown-black, with a fizzy head that fades quickly. Taste is really sort of non-existent. Little bitter, maybe? Palate is forgettable. Overall, a confused beer which needs to make up its mind. Oh yeah, Happy St. Patrick’s Day!

I was tricked into getting this while out to dinner.  From the bottle, looks okay but one taste will tell you this isn’t Guinness.  Watery and tasteless.  This beer should be put out of its misery and taken off the market.
Some guests brought to my St Patrick’s day shindig.  Pours black with fine head.  Nose of cocoa and malt.  Tastes of light malt, corn, chocolate, and earth.  Kinda watery and not much going on

WTF is this shit? Diageo, you should be ashamed of yourselves for taking the staid, respected Guinness name and affixing it to this. Black Lager is not a terrible beer,  yet it is so boring and thus offensive to me in principal that I refuse to give it a proper review here. Next time I see a sixer of this at the regular old grocery store and think "I need beer," I’ll walk ten more feet, get Yuengling Porter instead, and save $3. Change the name, cut the price, and you have another blah attempt at something "cool." Guinness, this is not. Special, no way. Tasty, meh, whatever.
Black in color with little white head. Smells and tastes like black liquorish. Has a slightly similar end flavor of a Guinness Stout, but not as good as that.

The big drawbacks are the strange aroma - kinda like marshmallows when they first hit the fire. The second shortcoming is the finish. It is in stark contrast with the roasty taste and is slightly unpleasant.
Rich color and head like guinness. Great look. It has rich, sweet coffee taste. Finish is slightly bitter. Not bad, very drinkable.
It’s like a thinner, more refreshing version of Guinness... nothing special.

Guinness Black Lager is kind of an odd duck. When beer pours near Coca-Cola black, one does not typically expect near Coca-Cola carbonation, as is the case with this one. Not an altogether bad thing, but sort of strange. As far as the balance of Guinness character and that of lager is concerned, flavor definitely lands in the latter territory, inasmuch as there is to speak of flavor at all in this beer. It is surprisingly devoid of appreciable nuance, really like if you took a bottled Guinness and mixed it with a light American lager 1:5 or so. A bit sweeter and more savory than a golden lager, it also fails to live up to the heartier expectations both the brand and coloration that this beer would typically inspire one to conjure. It is actually a bland offering, and for the lofty standards of its producers, I would consider this product to be a failure and one to skip, despite being at least drinkable and inoffensive.

330 ml bottle in Swords, Ireland. Pours a dark black color and has a thin tan head. Aroma is dark malts, chocolate and spices. Taste is smooth charcoal, coco, and malt. Palate is smooth but spiciy. Good

Overall decent and yummy, I am always up for something Guinness related and when I discovered this today I had to try it. I am not overwhelmed with its goodness  nor did I find it distasteful. Just a solid dark lager.

Expected dark color.  Smell pretty decent, sweet malt.  The taste is off however.  Tastes cheap.  It's almost as if the essence of Guinness was mixed with the essence of rolling rock.  If you are a Guinness fan, do yourself a favor and stick with the real thing.

Bottle. Pour is a dark brown with a very large head and aromas of faintly roasty malt. Flavor is a mess, though.  Like corn driven black lager.  I was hoping this would be alright.  It’s not for me.

330ml bottle pours black in color with a 2 finger creamy light tan head that leaves some nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is quite mild with some light toasted malts and mild chocolate and a slight sourness.  Taste is slightly sour with some malty sweetness and mild roast bitterness.  As far as dark lagers go, this one is average at best.
The aroma was like Guinness Stout but the beer was obviously thinner. Basically tasted like a slightly sweeter watered down Guinness stout.

Momma says always stress the positive, so I’ll say that Black Lager looks good. After that, well, (sorry mom) the roasted grain aroma is sharp and unpleasant, the beer is thin, and the finish leaves an unpleasant bitterness.

Pours black with a very thin head and medium lacing. Nose is pretty quiet, maybe a small hint of metal. Aromas are very light espresso, metal, water and some roasted malt. Tastes are light sweet, light bitter. Mouth is very watery with limited carbonation. Tastes almost like a diet coke. Meh.
NIce and refreshing. Interesting heavy aroma and nice aftertaste. Quite good if get it cold and nice thickness.

Bottle, first Schwarzbier. Aroma of barley. Taste is not strong, slightly malty, a hint of bitterness, but watery. not sure I like this type of beer. I certainly don't like this particular one.

An ok beer, but not what I expect from Guinness. I will not pass it up if it is offered to me.
No detectable hop flavor which is a plus for me. Nice thick head. Great aroma and caramel taste.
It doesn’t have that little bit of sour malt taste that a true Guinness has, but it’s really good...dark malt flavors balanced with bitterness, and much lighter than a Guinness.  I really liked it.

Bottle. A lightly bodied schwarzbier, this beer has a nice roasted barley flavor with a hint of brown sugar sweetness. On the watery side, there is a slight soft pillowy texture. Nothing wowing, but this is a solid brew.

From a bottle.  Aroma is roasty but comes across mild and thin. It was enjoyable, but you had to keep going back frequently to keep any ongoing taste.  Maybe that’s the intent?

Pours black with pillowy brown head.  sweet notes of caramel with that lovely lactic twinge.  Nice moderate mouthfeel with some watery character, chocolate and roast, sweet caramel and some lactic notes in the finish and after.  Pretty darn solid.
330ml Bottle. Dark brown with thick foamy tan head. Smell is malty. Taste is watery malt with slight hops around the edge. Really good and refreshing (nice during summer).
Solid, almost black body, with a rich tan head. Nice carbonation. Roast hops aroma with barley. Taste remarkably light given it’s dense body. Not bad, would drink again.

It smells good and I assume it smells like barely...cause it says so.
Its all dark and stuff, and i like that...beer and stuff.
it is a medium bitter, but flavorful.
I like the aftertaste because its not tooooo strong, but i like it....I would like to put my pinkie through your ear. cheers.
Well along with personal memories, I would rate this beer at a 15,,,oh wait, im uping that shit to 16!
Earthy and dark with nice amount of bitter taste. Smooth tasting as well and worth savoring.

It pours a sort of dark with some light showing through. The smell is a sweet, slightly roasted maltiness with some coffee hints. The taste lacks the creaminess of what I’m used to having when I grab a Guinness Draught, so kinda lacking all around, sweetness - not there, bitterness - not there, anything, yeah just bland. Reviewed 1/5/2013. 
11.2 oz bottle into a nonic pint glass.

A: Pours a very dark cola color with a good amount of opacity for the style. The head is a one finger heavy cream color that leaves behind a good amount of lacing. Poor retention, as expected from a lager.

S: A bit of roasted barley, chocolate...and corn adjuncts. Completely bland, rather than subpar.

T: Hey, a bit of roasted barley to open the flavor profile! That’s cool. The corn adjuncts seem to be muted, or at least more muted than I cynically feared. Finish is bit of fruity sweetness, lager crispness, and the faintest ’ping’ of chocolate. Better than I expected - but still, don’t let it warm up or the adjuncts will come out in full force.

M: Light and crisp, but not quite as dry as the bog-standard Guinness draught. The carbonation is fizzy and even intense as expected.

O: Not horrible. Wouldn’t seek it out or probably even buy again, but I’d gladly drink one if offered to me freely. This has its place being the weak link in the Guinness winter selection pack.
not sure why guinness is going into lagers but i did like it, quite light but the roast level is nice

Aroma has some crisp graininess with a medium roast character. A bit of a floral, fruity ester quality to the aroma. No diacetyl. The graininess and cracker notes are surprisingly strong and overwhelm the roast but somehow let the esters through. Pours black with some dark brown notes on the edges. A medium, tan head recedes fairly quickly leaving a persistent film on top and the edges. Taste has an odd sweetness to it which hits right away. Almost tart and a bit acidic which is very off putting. Finishes with a slightly astringent roast note. The esters aren’t as prevalent in the flavor. Light bitterness to it but no hop flavor. Mouthfeel is medium light bodies with medium carbonation. The astringency is medium low and alcohol warmth is very low. A bit watery. Overall the aroma to this beer is alright, but the acidity in the flavor is downright bad. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

So Guinness has decided to get into the lager game by making a black lager. What’s surprising is that this beer pretty much tastes and drinks like all the fizzy yellow European lagers it’s trying to distinguish itself from. If you’re expecting Guinness Stout in lager form you’re going to be disappointed. If you’re new to beer and want to try something a little different from the mainstream, then this might work for you.



I poured an 11.2oz bottle into a lager glass.



Appearance: Opaque black body with dark brown edges. Forms a large, light brown, soapy head which slowly evaporates but not completely and does leave some nice lacing on the glass.



Smell: Standard macro lager "beer" scent. Nothing skunky or sour, nothing inviting though.



Taste: The Schwarzbier style is an underutilized and underappreciated style, so part of me is happy to see one of the world’s biggest breweries bringing it mainstream. But on the other hand, Guinness Black Lager doesn’t exactly conform to the style very well. In a (literal) blind taste test I bet many people could mistake this for a "premium" European pilsner, but with a cleaner taste. That might actually be a selling point to some drinkers, however, "clean" isn’t really a complimentary description when it comes to a beer.



Despite the label’s indication that the beer is "cold brewed" (whatever that means) with roasted barley, there is little in the way of roasty character in the palate here. If you’re expecting a stout flavor or iced coffee taste you’re out of luck. In fact if you’re expecting any distinct flavor at all you might want to look elsewhere. This palate is bland - not bad - just bland. I really can’t pull anything memorable out of it. A bit maltier than your average macro lager, and thankfully no presence of adjuncts, but that’s about it. Mild bitterness through the middle and brief flashes of sweetness in the beginning and middle. Meh.



Drinkability: While Guinness Black Lager may not look like a typical macro lager, it drinks about the same. There’s noticeable fizziness throughout the mouth which helps impart the bitterness. It’s a bit smoother than most lagers, though the aftertaste isn’t quite as clean. At only 4.5% ABV it’s a borderline light beer, and would probably explain the mild palate.

finalmente la he probado y como lager oscura esta bastante buena.  recuerda a la canadiense pero con menos cuerpo

Pours a very dark brown color with a tan head that diminishes fast, leaves a sticky lacing that does not look all that great. Aroma is a strong malty earthy tone. It is kind of dry with some sort of coffee hoppy flavor. Over not to bad.

Black pour with off white head. Aroma is light roasted malt and a hinto burnt coffee. Flavor is pretty dry start with a semi sweet finish. A malt bitter and some nuttiness. Light/medium body with slightly foamy carbonation. A beer I liked more the 2nd time I had it.
Poured nice,lookes nice smells nice.  Watery with a musky aftertaste.  Blah....glad it was free.

Kudos to Guinness for at least importing this from Ireland. 

Roasty, black, cloudy, minimal head, medium bitterness, medium body, thin feel, average carbonation.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown with average, frothy beige head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, figs, raisins, faint earthy hops, sugar, and some funk. Flavor is malt forward followed by unbalanced fruit esters and hops; dry finish. Light/medium body and carbonation with low warmth.
Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, & some coffee; Flavor of burnt malt, caramel, coffee, hops, and some chocolate; Pretty decent for me.

Consumed at BTBF. Pours with a deep brown hued body with a small tan head that fades. Aromas are slightly sour, stale malt character, mild roasted barley character, a touch of hops, clean yeast wise. Flavors show a lot of stale malt, light sulfur, bready and sharp roast. Mild bubbles, pretty dry, thin. Pretty mild and stale tasting.

Keep in mind that I like bitter beers (porters) and I really enjoyed this beer.  it has some of the characteristics of a Guinness Stout, but not the heaviness.  Reasonably priced at $9 per 6 pack, this beer will definitely be one of my choices when I’m looking for something "lighter’ than my usual porters and stouts.

Poured from a bottle, Japan. Smells like metal shavings and fruit. Looks close enough to Guinness, a bit lighter with some red tones. Fizzy carbonation, tastes mildly bitter and sweet, with some malt and licorice, and a weakened Guinness flavor. Not crazy about it. Light body, a little bit creamy but not like a true Guinness.

Dark brown beer with reddish hues, and a white head. Very faint aromas of raisins, and caramel. Tastes of watery coffee, dark licorice, hints of raisins, and ends on a slightly smoky note. Simple, and very easy to drink beer. I like it.
Guinness WTF?  Please stick to what you are good at and what put you on the map.
(330ml bottle)  Pours an opaque black body with a small tan head.  Aroma of raisins, anise, chocolate, and roasted malt.  Flavor of raisins, roasted malt, anise, light ash, some chocolate, and plum.

Bottle pours black with medium light tan head.  Aromas are slight roast, but not much else.  Taste is like a very watery Guinness mixed with a very light lager.  Really can pound these, if you wanted.  Not bad, better than average lager.  Overall, decent for the style.  Do not get that this is a scharzbier, at all.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a medium sized beige head.  The aroma is almost non existent; the little bit that shows up is light roast and perhaps a splash of herbal notes and thin watery coffee.  The flavor has light roasted notes, light herbal notes, but is fairly bland overall as well.  There is a hint of bitterness at the back.  I would not revisit this again.

Single bottle purchased from a 7-11 on Kaua’i Island on 04/12/2012. Colour: Black. High off-white head. Nose: There is the roasted malt but with additions of yeast and splashes of cotton candy and late traces of BBQ sauce. Taste: Medium sweet, light bitter, medium-light sour. Well I expected some solid bitterness somewhere in this but it never showed up. Sweetness of is the malty variety and there is something pasty late. Just couldn’t get into this one.

Aroma is mild roast and some malt. Appearance is black with hint of brown red. Taste is nutty roast, earthy, minerally, chalky. Palate is light+.  Overall I do not enjoy this beer. More of a marketing gimmick than an attempt at a good beer.
Pours a brown-black with a tan head.  Smells muted, hint of bread - not much there.  Taste is mildly bitter and sweet, not much here either - a bit nutty.

Like the drink ability of this beer. I am a fan of dark beers and this one hits the mark. Best when it is at room temp. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pretty much what I expected. It tastes like Extra stout light with a little more of an earthy flavor. Not a bad beer but not a great one either
I thought it was pretty good. Kind of a barley flavor to it. I would definitely recommend it.
Bottle.  Not a bad beer.  Very little aroma but I have a cold.  Got a bottle of it for free.  It’s about the only way I would drink this again.  Not a lager fan but have enjoyed Schwarzbiers before.
I like this beer. Nice bite, not strong, but stays with you. Very light on the stomach, even with pasta. One can have as many as possible with this brand, and not get the "bloated belly" feeling.
Kinda dissapointed since its a guinness product...pours dark. ?aroma is nut chocolate  . ?taste is coffe chocolate skunky...just ok...

Thinly black beer with a beige head. Brown sugar, light roasted malts, a hint of fruit cake, and a whisper of caramel make up the aroma. It would be great, but it’s rather weak and diluted. The body is thin. The taste is bitter, with a dry finish and a pleasant but weak aftertaste of brown sugar. Pleasant, inoffensive, and manages to keep me from boredom.
Smells like drought and tastes a lot lighter, Its not a bad beer to drink but to many will most likely hurt your stomach.

To quote Ralphie, "it tastes like burning!" Pours dark brown with a thin, fizzy head. Faint grain aroma. Tastes like char (not in a good way) and feels kind of like a mouthful of ashes. Disappointing.
Fizzy mouth feel like seltzer water.  Your gums are tingly after sipping.  Very weak on aroma and flavor.  A very average brew.

Dark brown mahogany pour into the glass, with an initially wispy head that reduces to spotty lace.  The nose is of cereal and a just a hint of dough.  Flavors are reductive, roasted coffee essence and just a hint of black cherry.  It finishes with a roasted bitter.  The mouthfeel is almost seltzery, a tad thin.  The active carbonation separates the integration enough to make the brew somewhat out-of-balance.  It’s a shame, actually. I wanted it to be a bit better than it turned out.

Bottle. The pour was a murky dark brown with a slight reddish hue and an average sized (1-2 finger) light beige rocky head that reduced down to a few puddles of residue thus creating some excellent sheets of lace.

The aroma was of a roasted chocolate malt, a mild resin hop and a moldy yeast with notes of molasses and coffee.

The taste was very lightly sweet with a large dose of black malts and molasses early on and then became lightly bitter with a hint of coffee towards the end. The flavor lasted only a short time proceeding the swallow, with a malty coffee taste that was left to linger on the taste buds.

Mouthfeel was just under medium in body and a bit watery in texture with a nice medium carbonation.

Overall pretty much a typical Black Lager, nothing here to make it particularly memorable...

Malts. Oxidized malts. This is the reason why I simply don’t buy that macros have model QA/QC. Oxidized malts just shouldn’t slip by. And they should be consistent batch to batch. But this doesn’t happen. It never does. Here when the beer is cold it stands up to cursory inspection. Very dark, dark foam some faint to light aromas of dark caramel. OK. But as the beer warms to 50 it takes on wet tobacco, gummy, oxidized malt flavors. Still one of the better macro offerings but disappointing because of its changing over time.

From the bottle poured a dark brown brew with a thin light brown head that disipated quickly. not a lot of aroma, but a little roasty malt did I detect. Medium mouth feel and over all not bad, but not the reall deal.

Bottle. Faintly smells of urine on a pub floor- plus wheat cereal. Very dark with dissipating tan head. Tastes sweet then sour then sweet- but not in a pleasing way. Kind of cloying and thin at the same time.
black color, aroma of roasted malt, flavor of roasted malt, coffee, toffee, very watery, light bodied, nothing exciting

Pours black like a stout. Smells like a weak stout but way lighter body and weaker roast aroma. Tastes kind of like MGD blended with a subpar dry stout. Not impressed. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Picked up for $2 at the local beer store



A - light to medium brown



S - Smells like a guiness ale mixture. Very weak but some roasted and smoked malts.



T - Think a watered down Guinness. Very light very drinkable but not wsomething you’d want to drink



M - dry, mild bitterness, pretty disappointed



O - I’d get it again if it’s the only thing at a party. Other than that, not great.

Bottle pours deep brown with a khaki head. Aroma is somewhat burnt with heavy roast notes and maybe a touch of chocolate. Flavor shows the same with maybe a hint of coffee as well as a strange earthy characte (mushroom?). Overall body is light to moderate and the finish is pretty roasted.
Very dark brown. Cream colored head. Aroma is pure (over)roasted malt. Flavor is extremely roasty and has maybe a hint of burned coffee. Meh.
Deep brown pour with attractive tan, full head. Roasted malt, chocolate &no catanel subtly present in nose and flavor. Medium mouthfeel.

Appearance was ruby black with lasting 1 finger tannish creamy head, some lacing. Aromas where sweet roasted toasted toffee,coffee, caramel and touch of butterscotch. Hops where slight citrusy and spicey, no alcohol
 present. Taste was coffee and toffee followed by slight metallic herbal spuce pine. Palate was smooth with delicate body and creamy carbonation, average caulky finish. Warms up better, not. Happy St. Pattys to ya...

Poured from bottle.  Continuing with the st patty’s day theme.  Malt / sugar aroma.  Solid black, light tan head.  I taste roasted malt, a bit of hops, burnt caramel and honey (believe it or not!).   Beer is kinda average, but the dark honey flavor I’m getting wins it more points.
Bottle. Light malt aroma. Dark brown with a small tan head. Just like the aroma, a light malt flavor and a very slight lingering bitterness.  Generally speaking, not a lot of flavor. Light bodied.
Bottle. Drinking out of bottle. Can’t really smell anything. Flavor is like some other bland, dark lager ive had. Not bad. But nothing out of the ordinary.

Black.  Lightly roasted in the flavor and aroma with a thin palate.  Some grain, but really very little to enjoy here.  Thin, a little watery. Regular Guinness is better and this is surely nothing more than an attempt to break into the lager market.

This one is like the lable states it is black with a tan two finger head. The aroma is a citrus spice maybe cherry. Flavor is bitter with a copper finish. Palate is a little like water with slight carbonation. Over all not really what I expected from a Guinness, not a big fan but not a terrible beer.

Bottle from Total Wine.  Some guy was pouring samples of this and I had some.  Tasted pretty good, black color with a tan head.  Malts and plenty of carbonation in the taste.  Dark roasted flavors too.  Tastes like a weak version of extra stout.  Not bad..

Pours a deep black with small beige head.  Aroma is faintly caramel malt.  Mildly bitter with a touch of sweetness.  Light-to-medium bodied with a smooth finish.  This isn’t bad, somewhat better than regular Guinness.

Pours a deep brown with off white head. Nose and taste are more blah than I had hope & expected. I was expecting there to be a deeper malt and possibly roasty back taste. Not a beer I would buy again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From notes.  First reviewed 12/11/2011.  Poured from a 11.2 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The beer has a dark brown color that is a bit transparent, as bits of ruby sneak through the center and tint the edges. A fizzy white head rests on top and fades casually.

Mostly I just get a faint hint of roasted grains in the nose; sort of charred and bitter.

The flavor starts out with some dark roasted grains, a bit of coffee-like bitterness, and a bit of caramel sweetness. The second half of the sip is dominated by an earthy spiced yeast and skunky hops that remind me of ammonia. Not very good at all.

This is heavily carbonated and the fizzy nature of the beer gets in the way of the flavor. 

There were very few beer options at the event I was at, so it seemed like a good idea at the time. In retrospect, I probably should have seen this coming. This is something I will not be having again. At least since they are going for that ’import’ vibe I only had to have 11.2 oz. of this failed experiment.

Decent Beer. Nowhere near as good as the stout. Nothing special about it. Just tastes like a more roasted barley lager. More bitter. Decent head retention and head bubbles. Pours a dark black into a copper head loaded with bubbles.
On tap and served from a hot chick. That’s the first sign of a shitty beer. No roastedness. Just wet, but that’s only acceptable for whores.
It’s nothing special.  Pours a dark brown, taste is malty yet bland.  Nothing to truly distinguish this beer from the rest.  I’d take a Guinness stout over this any day.
Bottle. Pours a dark body with light head. Aroma is roast and Cheap malt lager.  Mouthfeel is thin.

Poured from a bottle into a mug.
Head: Little less than a finger high, white. Diminishes rather quickly leaving a thin layer that stays. 
Color: Black, not transparent
Aroma: Lightly skunky/sulfur, coupled with roasted malt/biscuit
Taste: Light roasted malts, not much else
Finish: Crisp, dry. Does not linger long past swallowing. 
Overall Impression: It is difficult to judge on merits of taste alone, separating from the unpleasant pungent aroma. Wondering if the case I purchased was old/stale. From a taste perspective, could be quite enjoyable if you are seeking a lager with mild hints of Guinness Stout.

bottle - Pours near black with a fast fading tan head that does not lace. The aroma is mild, roast malt. The flavor is roasted malt, somewhat sweet, with not much else going on. It’s bland and unimpressive. It’s not terrible, but it does seem fairly pointless.

Bottled 330ml @JFK Airport, NY

Dark brown color, good creamy beige head. Grainy, slightly toasted, ashy aroma. Light to medium bodied. Light toasted flavor, vegetables, a bit grainy. Fizzy, coloured pale lager. Waste of 9.99 dollars.

11.2 fl oz bottle poured into a dimpled mug. Deep brown amber with a tiny tan head. Aroma is roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is odd. It has the distinctive Guinness roastiness with the typical wateriness of a pale lager. Mouthfeel is a bit thin with a generous amount of carbonation.
