Finish is bitter roast at first and fades to a biscuity lager yeast. It is pretty much exactly what one would expect of a lager from Guinness. This isn’t bad but I don’t think I’ll buy it again. If I want a Guinness, I’ll buy a Guinness.

3/2/12 notes: bottle. Pour is black with brown and light ruby undertones. Aroma is musty, roasty, meaty. Flavor is a rather simple biscuit and roasted malt note, with a quick dry finish. Mouthfeel is predictably light and fizzy, which for better or worse is consistent with expectations from a Guinness “lager.” Drinks well with spicy, woodsy foods.

Dark pour small head not much to it.  Lightly toasty malt aroma a bit if bread pretty one note.  Avg pal maybe a touch thin.  Flavor is fine but bland toasty malt some light grain not something I’d drink again.
Bottle: Poured a black with a tan color head. Aroma is roasted malts. Taste is roasted malts/barely very smooth, yet has a bite as well to keep it lively on the tongue.

12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma and taste is basically roasted malts and a slight hop finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Kroger. Pours deep brown with a dissipating tan head. Nice black malt aroma. Lighter side of medium bodied with average carbonation and a smooth mouthfeel. Flavor burnt  malts with a moderate bitterness. Nothing exciting. Drinks pretty smooth like a Schwarzbier, but with that dark ashy Guinness trait.

Bottle.  Develops a decent head that lasts only if you drink it in 5-10 minutes.  Smells of chocolate, not chocolate milk chocolate, but yoo hoo chocolate.  Color is black.  Taste is very bland, even the first sip.  I should’ve known better, marketing to the American Adjunct Lager market.  Might as well buy Guinness Stout over this.
bottle. black with medium sized beige head. aroma of subtle milk chocolate and a touch of earth. flavor is similar with some soggy bread. meh.

12oz bottle...poured out black with normal guinness head that quickly disappears. the aroma if any was from roasted malts. flavor wise i got nothing out of it but a very mild malt taste. not sure what i was expecting but was not it...

Bottle poured into a Shaker at Old Chicago, Colorado Springs.  Color is black with very low carbonation and a tan ring for a head.  Aroma is a sweet candy like malt scent.  It has a lighter medium body that goes down with a thin crisp mouth feel.  Flavor is a light roasted taste that seems to have a cola like feel.  After taste is clean with just a hint of the roasted taste trying to hang on.  Overall I don’t like it much, it may be what they wanted it to be but, I think its just to thin.

poured deep,brown/black with a huge oatmeal coloured head.  scent is slightly coffee.  Taste is very weak coffee, cola, only slightly bitter.  Decent flavour--only there’s almost none OF it. Certainly not what one expects with the name "Guinness" on it.  Disappointing.

11.2oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours very dark brown with a light beige head.  Aroma of lightly roasted and pale malts plus a little bit of hops.  Flavor sort of bland, but not terrible.  Average texture.  A decent beer.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown, nearly black with slightly off white head. Aroma is a slightly fruity roast caramel. The flavor is very light roast caramel. Not bad for a brew that is trying to appeal to the "masses", but not very good, regular guiness stout much better!!
Dark brown with a one finger tan head that didn’t hold that well but did leave a nice lace. smells and taste of mild roasted malt a light hop taste smooth light mouthfeel ending slightly dry.

Bottle. Very dark brown to black pour with a light tan head. Aroma of roasted grains and a hint of sour fruit. Palate is thinnish. Taste is mildly roasty, somewhat metallic, and a grain theme throughout. Just okay.

I do not like this beer much. It’s better than a Bud Lite. It is nice-looking with its darkness and all, but there’s no taste! A beer should taste like something. It’s just bland in aroma, taste and palate. Not recommended if you are trying to find a tasty brew.

Bottle. Pours dark ruby black with beige head. The aroma is caramel with some hints of ash, cherry, and raisin. The flavor is quite tinny with some hints of ash, caramel, and dark chocolate. There’s a strange hay-like thing in there, too. Finish is kind of hollow with a hint of raisin. Meh.

Bottle. Dark mahogony-black beer with a tan head. Light roast and light grain aroma. Malt and light toffee flavor with light roast and light mineral. Medium bodied. Malt and light toffee lingers with light roast.
Similar colour to the Guinness Stout although the head has notably less head with larger bubbles. Virtually no aroma. Taste is very lagery, some bitterness. Okay.

355ml bottle. Thick oily black looking with a great big light brown head I’d deep foam. Aromas of roasted malt with some bitterness on the palate and a dry roasty flavour. A bit thin in the mouth but overall okay.

Bottle...  Poured (not "straight from the bottle") a near black with hints of brown and red with a thick forming, bubbly, khaki head. WOW! Cold brewed for maximum enjoyment.  Sort of underwhelming but not offensive.  Clean, with barley grains, roast, nutty, cocoa powder, some malt sweetness.  A little bit of fruitiness but low esters and yeast presence.  Would rather have a Session Black.
A bit disappointed with Guinness as there is nothing that really stands out.  It is a middle road though for Lager fans wanting to try something darker.

Bottle.  Medium brown with thin light tan head.  Kind of tastes like a watered down spritzier uinness without all the chalkiness of guinness.  The aromas and flavors are weak as expected but it drinks suprisingly well.  Maybe I just like it for its unique qualities among the beers I’ve been ticking.  Tock.
This poured a reddish color with a beige head. Aroma was of light roast, metla and not much else. Taste was very metllic and bitter, but not from hops, in an astringent way, and lioght roast. Bleh.

Dark / black.  Good head.  A burnt bitter aroma with a good hit of roasted malt in the taste.  The slightly bitter taste (not from the hops) takes you through to the finish.  It feels like very little hops were used in this one.

A friend of my sister brought a 6 pack at home.Well , i am a fan of Guinness Draught but this Black Lager its kind of a un-carbonated beer with Stout malts and almost no hop pressence ,what its good its that its quite drinkable but not much idionsincratic taste like other products from this brand ,really.Average/Forgettable beer.

Black with a thin head. Some maltiness and bread on the nose. Smooth entry leading to a mildly carbonated, light mouthfeel with a finish having hints of vanilla and milk chocolate. Some metallic notes.
Not too bad but far from impressive.  Pours a dark brown with a bubbly tan head.  Slight roasty aroma.  Pretty thin beer.

11.2 ounce bottle from Remke/biggs in Westen Hills, tasted on October 27, 2011.  Almost opaque dark brown hue, small tan head that slowly departed with good lacing, aroma of good malt and not-so-good wet cardboard, sweet malty taste with some slightly unpleasant characteristics,bitter and rather astringent finish.  Better than the smell would indicate but not big enough to compete with better examples of the style.  I think the Guinness name should be attached to better beers.

12 oz. bottle. Pours nice lager head but with a stout head color. Smell does have those roasted barley notes, just less prominent than in the real Guinness. The main thing that makes this not a real Guinness is the forced carbonation with no nitro and no widget. We’re left with a halfway decent black lager that’s aimed at people who might like Guinness if it were a lager and just as fizzy as a Lite.

Bottle. Very handsome pour: deep, clear mahogany with a chunky light brown head that shows nice retention and lacing. Aroma is so weak as to be almost nonexistent, even after lots of breathing time. Vaguely sweet and papery. Much can be said about the flavour too. In a blind tasting I’m not sure if I would actually be able to say that there is roasted malt in here. Amazing considering the appearance and pedigree of this beer. If they’re looking to capture the bland lager-drinker market, they’ve made a good thrust in the right direction. Watery and lifeless, with hard carbonation. A shadow of a schwarzbier.
Bottle. Low to medium body. Very malt forward, not roasted however. Hardly any hops at all.

11.2oz bottle.  Cold brewed, how ’bout that.  Mellow black malt aroma.  Pretty much a straightforward Schwarz/Dunkel.  Overly sweet, I’m not sure who they were thinking of selling this to.  Not a bad beer, if I were in Germany.  Distant smoked coffee tones, there is some nice roastiness.  Some bitterness behind the chocolate notes.  Enjoyable enough beer, just a mystery as to why Guinness would feel the need.

Bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of roastiness, light fruittiness and a hint of carmel. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of roastiness, light carmel and a hint of fruittiness with a crisp lingering roasty finish.

A black pour with a lasting beige head with good lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel,barley with some chocolate notes. Taste same as aroma with some light bitterness. Palate is a medium body with moderate carbonation. Finish is roasted dark malts, barley, some yeasty notes with some light hops on the end. Seems a bit lacking in flavor and aroma for this style but drinkable. Overall nothing really remarkable, an average brew

Black with a lager type of head which is an tan color. Very carbonated. Mild sourness. Chocolate malty. Crisp for a dark beer. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Velvety smooth a bit of the Guinness Stout taste to it. Not rough or bitter nothing offensive about this. Says roasted malts but anything flavorful has been roasted out of here. Easy drinking though I did have a strange feeling in my belly after one of these I don’t get with other beers. Not sure where this fits in teh beer market. A far cry from the good Schwarzbiers that are out there. Had to try it thats about it.

Pours a thin black with a medium tan head. Aroma is mild with hints of roasted malt. Flavor is rather watery  with roasted malt and metallic notes and hints of chocolate, caramel, and grass. Thin body with medium carbonation. Just too thin and watery with not much flavor.

Malty aroma has a smoky undertone and a firm yeasty note. It pours an opaque dark-chocolate brown with a thick, frothy, light tan head. Malty, smoky flavor has hints of molasses, licorice and coffee. Texture, unfortunately, seems to be on the thin side, though it has a good fizz. OK, but their classic stout is still the best. On tap.

Not really a schwarz, but a mediocre Irish lager with some additional barley. Aroma of stale malt, and tastes like Killian’s (not) Irish Red. Oily brown appearance, but fairly thin of body. Stick with the stout lads.

Pours dark brown. not black.  Head fades to a film over the course of a few minutes.  Nose is pretty bland but lends some evident roast and sugary sweet malts.  Flavor is some roasted malts, biscuit malts and dry bready finish.  Bitterness is low sweetness is low.  Mouthfeel is light and smooth.  This one isn’t bad but doesn’t have anything that makes it stand out as anything other than macro crap.

Appearance: liquid charcoal and ash under a light khaki head which fades into a lacey collar. A puddle hovers in the middle. Swirls thick and puffy with more lace.


Nose: dry burnt ashen barley and nuts. Dry coffee grinds. Burnt toast – black. Old dried hops and roasted barley grains.


Palate: dry and roasted with a very very dry finish or burnt barley and burnt nuts. Pumpernickel and grapes – thin and watery mouthfeel. Parching acridity – ash, brittle burnt bread crusts, burnt smoldering woods. Coffee grinds.


Final Thoughts: wow. Even more forgettable than the Guinness Draught. Thin, watery, ashy, dry, unassuming, and not very well balanced. I watch the commercials for this beer and find myself laughing at the sheer absurdity; sure, I’d have goose bumps…goose bumps of disgust.

11.2 fl oz bottle at Burger & Beer Joint, Miami Beach, FL. Sampled on January 22, 2012.
Dark reddish brown to black color, huge lasting tan head. Sweet, cream, a bit roasted scent. Roasted, malty, cream taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium low bitterness.
I’d drink it again given the chance.
Bottle to pint glass.  Pours an opaque black with sparse head.  A bit watery, and malty flavors.  Not too much bitter bite, and there is surprisingly little aftertaste.  Not bad.

dark maple in color foamy tan head. Roasted barley light caramel aroma with a some metallic notes. Almost no sweetness with a light roasted barley on the flavor, slight grass. Light bitterness. Bland overall. Should not have to try to taste different complexities, they should come out at you.
Opaque black with a good head and lace.  Roasted malt and a light bittering are the whole story here.  Easy to drink because there is so little going on.  Not bad at all, just not very much to it.

12 oz. bottle served in shaker- poured a near black with a sharp maroon tint when held to a light source, mildly creamy darkened tan head and gently whisped away.  Hearty aroma of roasted barley with a mild note of hops.  Hits the mouth with a firm medium body, roastedness of the malt is not subtle at all- but I like it that way, holds up well in the middle, finish has a bittering feeling that wants to linger, but goes away much faster than I would like.  I call this one deadly- damn near had the whole six pack in less that 15 minutes last night.  It wasn’t until running back to the fridge that I saw I had 1 bottle left.  Very solid sessioner.
11.2oz bottle-pours black with a big tight tan head.  Aroma is roasty dark malt, earthy.  Taste is roasty dark malt, 2nd earthy hops.  Medium Body.
12oz bottle. dark black, thin lasting tan head. light aroma of roast. taste is a bit thin, not a lot going on, a little roast.

12 oz. bottle purchased at QFC in Mukilteo/Harbour Pointe, WA.  Pours a VERY dark brown with a minimal tan colored head.  Aroma:  Roasted malt.  Flavor:  Same as the aroma, with a hint of coffee.  Light bodied and delicious.

Pours a very dark brown, not totally black, with a nice tan head. Aroma is mildly roasty. And flavor is mildly roasty. Shockingly little going on here. Sent a search party out for flavor and couldn’t find hardly anything even after I boldly ignored the bottle instructions and allowed it to warm up - in a glass. At least nothing offensive here. I kinda liked this one looking forward to the next one.
Black with tall foamy tan head.  Grassy, corn aroma.  Taste - roasted malt and grassy hops.  Notes of coffee and toast.  Medium body.  Easy drinking, but overall rather boring.  Just ok for me.

Black in color, clear with a thin white head.  Good dark malt and lager aroma.  I found this a very easy drinking nice dark beer.  This is a great beer for when you want some flavor but not the heaviness.  i liked the flavor.

Bottle and served in Guinness pint glass: Pours a deep brown with reddish highlights topped by a fizzy head and spotty lace. The aroma has notes of ashy, roasted, and bready malts, some dark fruit and a hint of soapy yeast. The taste is utterly ordinary, simple sugars, sweet malt, heavy wet grains and a touch of herbal Continental hops. The mouth feel is watery and fades into a distance far too quickly. Even for a session Schwarzbier this lacks any real German character. Honest it was what I expected... sadly. (The McSorleys Irish Black Lager is world class compared to this)

The best way to describe this beer is mix 50% Guinness with 50% Michelob Ultra... It has a very good taste, then after you swallow , the taste disappears like Ultra does? So? Less filling / Tastes great while in mouth?

I was really looking forward to this one.  Any expectations I held were immediately snuffed out with the first sip.  It seems to be a pale lager with just enough roasted malt to color it - which is very little.  What is "cold-brewed", anyway??  Very thin body, very abrupt finish.  May be a passable "lawnmower beer", except for the price.

Pours dark brown with a large fluffy head. Smells like a dark malted lager. Tastes mildly malted and mildly hoppy. Light-bodied with a wet texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Guinness Black Lager finishes rather blandly.

Bought at Krogers.
Black. Med. creamy, beige head. Aroma: Roasted chocolate malts. Flavor: Roasted coffee, like a light Stout. Roasty, clean finish.

Ignoring the directions to drink straight from the bottle, I poured it into aglass. Poured a thin short lived head, over a clear, brown (SRM 30) body....nose is hints of coffee, chocolate (my imagination may have run rampant),, strong cereal....taste is ligth cereal malt, finishing with a bit of bitterness.....mouth feel light and watery, carbonation adds a sharp tongue startling bonk. This is not a Schwartzbier. It is a Pale Lager dyed black. When the brewery tells you to drink it from the bottle, it means "it don’t have no aroma". BJCP 5/3/9/4/5

Bottle from the state store 

Appearance: Black with with a medium sized beige head and good lacing 

Aroma: Toasted malts, toffee, smokey and woody 

Taste: Toasted malts, toffee and herbal 

OK, but I won’t be buying it again

12 ounce bottle

Aroma: minimal aroma- slight roasted malts, sulfur

Appearance: solid black, no head

Taste: some roasted malts, touch caramel sweetness

Palate: thin, highly carbonated

Overall: This is a very boring beer. Bland and no character to it at all.

Bottle from pikapp327.  On a night filled with cheap malt liquor, I was really hoping this would be the stand out beer of the night.  Dark pour with a small tan head.  Aroma is faintly roasted and pretty subdued.  Taste is milky sweetness, sour grain, and a little more roast.  Oh well.

Bottle courtesy Fratto via pikapp327. Im already confused. This beer pours super dark. Black and brown color. Tan foamy head. Aroma is lightly chocolate and metallic. Flavor is dry, metallic, and a slight bit gross. No thank you.

Very dark brown / black pour. The aroma is off, slight roasted malt, licorice, but also an uncharacteristic earthy mushroom aroma. Smells oxidized. Dissipates as the brew warms, but off putting at first. Light bodied, high carbonation, watery palate. Slight roasted malt, slight hoppiness, abrasive finish.

Bottle. Pours black with a small white-ish head.  Pretty light on aroma but there is some malty scent with some light roasty notes.  Taste is a light lager.. some well done barley in the mix.  This is pretty decent but way overpriced.

I did not care one bit for this brew. Something sort of "off"/bitter in the aftertaste that was just a downer.  Aromas were weak as well as the flavors.  Very thin and watery in texture.  Only upside was the excellent lacing on the glass (but who wants to pay for that?!).
This beer is highly carbonated with a thick head. I get a taste of roasted malts and carbonation. It has a nice black color!!

Bottle.  Near black color with a small off white head.  Roasty aroma with hints of coffee.  Roasted malt flavor with a slight chocolate sweetness.  Well carbonated with a dry, watery texture.  Easy drinking but void of much taste.

Close your eyes and the aroma would convince you that perhaps you were sniffing over a German pilsner.  Nice noble bouquet.  Perhaps a little sulfur.  Very, very dark mahogany with a thick tan head that falls rather quickly (unlike the ale).  Remarkably smooth mouth feel with a nice light level of carbonation.  Flavors are not as bitter as I would have anticipated although the sweetness is subdued as well.  Definitely some dark fruits and carmel notes.  Light finish.  Actually quite refreshing.
Nice light swartzbeer. Watery with a decent roast malt and a highly carbonated pour and mouthfeel.
Bottle.  Pours brown to black, with a medium sized beige to tan head.  Roast, thin malt on the nose, grainy toast.  Thin and roasty.  Basic shwarzbier.  Grain and roast.  Meh.
Caramel malt aroma on this dark brown brew.  Roasted flavor with a sweet finish.

Not much going on with this beer.  The jet black appearance and the relatively strong carbonation are the strongest features of this beer.  Aroma is very thin.  Appearance is black, obviously, with slightly reddish overtones.   Taste is thin:  very slight resin hops, slightly sweet caramel initial flavor, improving in amplitude within the mouth, with a slightly bitter finish.  Not a bad beer, but definitely not a good one.  Other schwarzbiers offer a lot more flavor than this one.

Bottle from Capone’s.  Pours thick jet black with tan head.  Nose is like a hoppier regular Guinness.  Tastes malty, with resiny hops, less malt character than regular Guinness, and a lackluster body.  A disappointment that just might change the joke where Arthur Guinness, Pete Coors, and Augie Busch sit around discussing beers.

Bottle:  The aroma consists of really light chocolate, nuts, and a hint of grass.  It pours a dark brown with some red highlights when held to the light.  It has a two finger beige head that leaves behind some spotty webbing for lacing.  The flavor starts with light chocolate and caramel.  The finish has some light nuttiness, roast, and a hint of fruit.  It’s light bodied with lively carbonation that borders on being prickly.  Overall, it’s sort of a Schwarzbeir-light.  While there’s nothing offensive, there isn’t exactly a lot to like about it either.
Bottle.  Woody chocolate malt aroma.   Dark brown color with giant tan head..   Lightly sweet chocolate malt flavor.  Very light body.  No bad flavors but extremely light.
Bottle. Black color. Tan head. Weak nose of malt and coffee. Flavor of toasty malts and coffee, but very weak and watery. Not the best black lager. Not as good as I expect from Guinness.

Bottled. Poured dark brown with a tight cap of beige head.  The aroma was really sweet with toasted black malts and vanilla.  The flavor found artificially-sweetened toasty black malts, vanilla, and a pinch of cocoa.. aspartamey on the quick finish.. OK, but not by any means exciting.  Lighter-bodied with prickly carbonation on the palate.. clean and calculated.. too sweet.

Bottle.
Pours a beautiful black with a nose of coppery chocolate and a light caramel.  Flavor is an upfront chocolate chip with a quick backwash of copper.  Watery mouthfeel.  Bleh.

Bottle. Clear, dark brown with a small beige head. Light aroma of doughy malt and some cocoa. Flavor is mild and malty with some faint bitterness. Medium to light body with mild carbonation and a thin, watery mouth feel. Not too impressed with this, no major faults, just bland and watered down.
Bottle.  Wow cold brewed!  thanks for telling me bottle.  I apreciate Diageo’s attempts to diversify to non traditional styles but  the marketing on this was embarrasssing.  It’s ok though.

Before I popped the top I read the label and these words food out, "Enjoy ice cold straight the bottle".  I assume these words are for macro drinkers.  Rather bland Schwarzbier more like a dark pale lager with a hint of roasted malts.   What’s next from Guinness, Black Ultra Lager?
Bottle.  Pours a thin black.  The flavor is of roasted malt, kind of like a stout yet has a lager like quality to it.  Not overly carbonated.  Decent overall.
Pours dark reddish brown from 12 oz bottle.  Not terrible.  Smooth.  Roasted barley is nice, but thin as hell and no aroma I can detect.  Sessionable?  Sure.

Pours dark brown to black with a creamy, tan and semi lasting head. Aroma is roasted malty and light breadish, mild cornish too. Cornish, toasted malty and dark breadish. Light metallic and bitter flavoured. Dark roasted and dry finish.

Pours a very dark brown, not totally black, with a nice tan head.  Aroma is mildly roasty.  And flavor is mildly roasty.  Shockingly little going on here.  Sent a search party out for flavor and couldn’t find hardly anything even after I boldly ignored the bottle instructions and allowed it to warm up - in a glass.  At least nothing offensive here.  Carbonation is actually sort of prickly and distracting, seemed sort of odd and out of place.

Poured with a black body and a quickly fading tan head. Aroma had a roasted malts and a slight peat presence in the back.  Flavor was well balanced roasted malts were mild and the smoke we delicate.  Although it was balanced it was rather light which was disappointing.   Slightly over carbonated, not bad but not good either.

Bottle; poured a dark brown, essentially black, color with a cocoa colored head.  Aroma of minerals, cocoa, caramel; aroma was a bit off for me.  Flavor was a bit bland, they were likely targetting a mass appeal with this one.  Some roasted, cocoa and mineral-like notes.  Not bad, just not much going on.

33 cl. Opaque black with a ring of cream. Mild aromas of coffee, caramel, and a whiff of earthy vegetables. Flavor starts the same, but develops more char, and then touches of iron, tart apple, sour cream, and brown sugar. Medium body is well-balanced, but has a bit too much carbonation.

Bottle... Pours nearly black with a small, flimsy, mushroom-colored head. Good creamy retention. The aroma offers light notes of dark chocolate and espresso, but is mainly just bland as I had to really dig my nose deep into the glass to pull out anything at all. Medium-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and tingly carbonation. The flavor is mildly roasty and perfectly balanced, but for the most part, it’s just bland, mundane and fairly lifeless. Finishes crisp and a tad roasty, but mostly just clean.

Bottle @ home. Deep brown appearance with a light brown head. Roasty dark malty, grassy, hay aroma. Deeply roasty malty, light espresso, hay, straw flavor. Light bodied. Pretty gross. Fuck I made some bad choices on my mixer sixer tonight.
Bottle - pours solid black with a medium tan head. Tastes like watery burnt toast.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours black with dark brown highlights and one inch light brown head.  Some lacing, medium body, light/medium texture, and roasted malt aroma.  Taste is roasted malt and some grassy hops in the finish.
Looks like a stout, but the taste is all lager. Nothing special about this at all. Very disappointing.

Location: 11.2 oz bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 12/5/11




Aroma: The nose is fairly light, with some roasted notes, toast/bread, and a hint of chocolate


Appearance: It pours a dark brown color with a fizzy light brown head, and some spotty lace


Flavor: The taste is light-medium sweet, somewhat roasty/toasty, with just a hint of bitterness


Palate: The body is light, it is a little bit too watery, with a tingly mouthfeel, and a fairly short duration


Overall Impression: 
Alright, so I’ve seen enough commercials for this one to last me a lifetime.  Well, I guess my expectations were a little to high here.  It is pretty much just an adjunct watery attempt at a Schwazbier.  At least I could tell what style they were going for, I’ll give them that.

From the Int’l great Beer Expo.  I expected not to like this beer.  The aroma is smokey, roasty, burnt caramel.  The appearance is lightly translucent brown, red hue.  The flavor is just like the aroma, very enjoyable.  The finish was sweet, with some piney hops.  This was pretty good, and defied my expectations.
Like I rated their 250 ann stout, this is the best Guinness can do? really? Your one of the best known brands in the world and you throw this crap out to the public. dissapointed.
Pours a pitch black. Aroma is slightly malty. Not much to it. Flavor is just as light. Very meh.
(bottle) black with tan head. Roast malt aroma with a hint of hops. Flavor is roast malt with a grassy hops bitterness in the finish.

Medium brown with a small off-white head.  Light herbal aroma with a hint of roasted malt and semi-sweet chocolate shavings.  Flavor is lightly roasted malts with a bit of sweetness,  light herbal hops bitterness.  The finish is quick and lightly bitter with an active carbonation and a slightly watery but dry, crisp feel on the palate.  It’s really not that bad but nothing spectacular.

Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a large creamy beige head that faded fairly quickly and left a bit of lacing. The aroma was a bit skunky, sour, tangy and industrial. The flavor was bitter, tangy and industrial with a sour, corny and almost medicinal undertone. Medium finish, smooth body. Blah.

bottle... dark brown with a medium tan head, decent one finger head lingers but it looks watery, no lace... the aroma is aroma, generic molasses syrup and wet dog, a bit of char tree bark, yum...the taste is equally bad, wet dog, very generic, just garbage

12oz. bottle.  Did not drink this "ice cold" or straight from the bottle.  What’s the matter, Diageo?  Afraid I might actually taste it or something?  Anyway, on with the rating:       Aroma of roasted malt with a hint of sourness, perhaps some lighter notes of chocolate and sulfur.  Black in color with dark brown around the edges and a foamy, lasting, light tan head.  Flavor profile is dry, roasty, lightly charred malts, with tinges of herbal hop flavor and a moderate amount of bitterness late, along with very faint touches of dark chocolate, smoke and again, that trademark Guinness sourness.  Active, effervescent, dry and sharp on palate, no nitro widgets to be found here.  Body is light-medium.  Easy to quaff, for sure.  Ultimately, about what I was expecting, which is why I only picked up the one bottle.

Pours a dark brown to black with a medium chocolate head. The first hint of aroma I got was a sour smell but I also got some hints of chocolate malt and hops. The taste is lacking any real distinction but it is not unpleasant. Thin and light body. Not something I will be drinking unless I’m not buying.

Combine classic Guinness with an everyday lager and this is what you get. PLeasant aroma and classic Guinness appearance but the taste falls short of what I would label a Guinness. It is what it is. An attempt, albeit a good one, at pushing Guinness to the ultra mainstream.

11.2oz bottle. Pours black with a slight off-white head. Nice looking dark brew but it is basically just an average tasting macro lager. I would expect more from the name on the label but nothing special here.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (roasted/burnt grain, husks), with light notes of paper and paint.

Flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter, husky, unclean/papery.

Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

About as industrial as it gets. Drain pour.

12 oz Bottle:  Aroma is roasted malts, light caramel, a very slight grass hop texture, and little bit of cardboard.  Appearance is black but light can be seen through it with a thick sightly tan, but more white head.  Taste is malty,  very light chocolate notes, then into a grassy hop, and finishes a little bit fry.  Palate is very carbonated in the mouth, leaving you with a dry slightly tingling feeling on your tongue.  Overall, Nothing really bad about this beer.  Maybe the cardboard notes in the scent, but decent.  Cheers!
Bottle To Pint Glass. Pours black with a decent tan head.There is a slight roasted malt flavor with an odd finish after. Gotta admit, was hoping for more

Nose is light bread and roasted notes. Poured a dark brown with minimal light brown head/big bubbles. Tasted like sweet, light roast on the initial sip, then all bread and hay on the end with some bitters. Not bad but not the best by any means.

Yeah...  this beer is pretty much junk. Guinness, guinness. This beer smells fine but not great. It smells like a black lager. Already an awkward style. It takes meek and boring. Nothing bold or unique about this beer. meh
This beer was very weird to me it was a lager with that close taste to the draught style

SHOCKINGLY disappointing!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Nice malty, nutty, roasted aroma. Very nice. Gorgeous cola black pour with an outstanding brown creamy head that dies a bit too soon. After that it sucks! Very thin, very, very watery. No flavor, no body, no character, no after-taste...NOTHING! I’m stunned that Guinness of all brewers would come out with something this useless!  The appearance and aroma bumped the score up. Don’t let my 2.1 fool you! Overall, this sucks ass!

Bottle.  Just noticing that its only 11.2 ounces.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Little aroma, a bit of coffee. Flavor is predominately a burnt, with roasted barley coming through a hint of hops at the end.  Overall okay.

Pours a dark cola color with aroma of roasted malt.  Taste is thin with little complexity.  Great advertising because I was expecting so much more from this beer.  Overall a drinkable beer that lacked flavor.

11.2 oz. bottle- Poured into a glass against what the directions say- Pours dark brown with little transparency and a thin tan head. Aroma is all roasted malts and it’s a bit nutty, ha ha. The flavor is roasted malts and subtle coffee shows itself, sweet and sessionable. The body is slightly watery, but I am beginning to respect that, not everything has to be thick as tar, carbonation is moderately high. Decent beer, it doesn’t deserve the rock bottom reviews here.
Bottle. Poured black with a tan head. Aroma of dough, vegetable, and toasted malt. The flavor found mainly toasted malt. Light body.

Bottle.  Why did I get so excited to see this ... something different from Guinness.  But in the end it comes across as just another macro, albeit dark and roasty.  Drinks with a sweet, malty edge, and lacking any serious bodily strength.  So-so at best.  (#4356, 11/17/2011)

Pours dark black with nice lacing tan head, aroma brings notes of some weird vegetal, touch of roast, hints of grain maybe? Very fizzy and thin on the palate, taste is thin as well with hints of slight roast, some odd metallic notes, hints of grain, very slight hint of roast, leaving an unpleasant metallic and sweet combination at the end.

[Bottle] Pours a very dark brown color with a rocky looking brown head. Aroma is of roasted malts, anise and light ash. The taste is of roasted malts, brown sugar, hints of smoke, mild nuts and metal. Generic sweetness lingers in the finish. Light in body. Pretty much exactly what I expected from Guinness. Not too bad.

12 oz bottle, poured into a lager glass,  black in color with frothy head with a little lacing on the glass. Aroma is decent beer with a hint of citrusy smell. Taste is clean, crisp, palate is thin and watery, good lager flavor. Lively CO2, good Black Lager.

Bottle served in a Guinness pint. Black in color with a medium-large khaki head. Short retention, decent lace. Aroma is tinny, lightly roasted malt. Flavor the same. Light-medium, body, thin creamy texture, and a soft, short finish. Easy drinking, not very interesting.
aroma is a bit sour.  pours dark black.  Highly carbonated in a bubbly sort of way.  Taste is a bit thin.  not a big fan.
WOW!  This stuff did not taste like I expected it to, it was wayyyy better than I had hoped.  Goes down smooth just like any other lager, but has that oaky almost German quality to it.
Green bean aroma. Clear mahogany, medium tan head, nice lacing. Thin body. Dry cola and cardboard flavor. I enjoy Guinness’ stouts, so I had higher hopes for this. Such a disappointment,
Black and clean. Pours with a good but big bubble frothy head. Runny aroma. Good light roasty malt taste with a thinner consistency.

Bottle at the International Great Beer Expo in Uniondale.  Pours black with a tan head.  There is a trace of roasted malt in the nose and that is about it.   The flavor is weak roasted malt and stale cardboard.  Light-medium bodied.  Thankfully, I was able to sample this at the festival so I won’t have to waste my money buying it.

Bottle purchased @ Smiley’s Discount beverage, Dover, NH for $1.59.  Deep brown pour into a pint. Soapy head, light lace. Nose of roasted barley. A slight smokiness with a roasted malt backbone. A tad thin in the body. Much better than I thought to was going to be.

Bottle at World of Beer (Carrollwood).  Black pour with a tan head.  Not a whole lot going on in the aroma other than some roasted malt notes.  Flavor is decent but again not very exciting.  Fairly watery mouthfeel.  Easy drinking but I prefer more character in a Schwarzbier.
12oz bottle at Chad and Monica’s house. Overall, better than average. Nice roasted malt and a hint of smokiness. Very easy drinking and a nice change of pace.

aroma of ordinary beer with a bit of extra malt and earth. spicy tingle and dishwater hop to this complex yet not substantial brew that is watery. earth, a bit of anise and a slight slickness with a bit of sharp bubble leave me with the impression that this is a crafty brew made by a crafty brewer. some roast and dark style sweetness.

Bottle, a gift from a customer who brought this into the store for me. Thank you, person I can no longer remember. A touching gift, ruined by the fact that I’m a terrible, ungrateful person. Now, on the beer! Bottle, served at home, out off my Maudite glass; pours clear black; 1-finger pale tan head, average lacing. Nose is garbage-water (no really, I’m trying not to be a dick, but this smells rather like old dishwater), flint, bacon, hot dumpster (serious overripe vegetables here) , and some vague roast. Flavours are rather soapy, with light roast pervasive right through, more boiled vegetables. Terrible. Just terrible.

Bottle. Pours a dark black color with a thin, lacing head. Light, roasted malt aroma. Watered down taste with some malt and oats lingering around. Not the best beer, but my expectations were minimal to begin with.

Bottle. Black pour with a medium, dense brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, charred grains, cold coffee and faint chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, toasted grains, dark bread, ash, and cold coffee. Body is medium with a soft, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more roasted malt, light ashy notes, toasted grains, dark bread, coffee and light chocolate.

I recently took a trip to Ireland, where I knew that the Black Lager was out there, but never made it to the glass. Guinness Stout is so prevelant over there it was like drinking iced tea here in Dixie. The Black lager has a nice aroma and good flavor. It has a slightly-less-than medium body and is not nearly as filling as the stout. It’s a good lager, as far as that goes, but when is comes to Guinness, the stout is king.

11.2 fl oz bottle at Llywelyns Pub in Overland Park, Kansas. Pour is black brown and some ruby, with a loose 2 inch tan head that is rocky, and falls pretty quick. OK lacing. Aroma is really faint, though it was cold. Some sweet malt, whisper of roast malt, that’s about it. Taste is mildly sweet malt, then a mineral light ashy roast finish. Simple, but clean. Palate is light to bodied, dry, crisp finish. Mild sweet finish, a bit of char lingers past that. Overall, easy drinking with enough flavor to be interesting.

Part of a mixed six pack. I didn’t drink it ice cold out of the bottle, rather I poured it into a Guinness glass at a good 10° above ice cold. Light roast in the nose. Dark brown color with red tinting and a one fingered tan head. Some roast, some malty sweetness, a bit of an off-putting vegetal flavor (DMS?). Very light bodied and pretty smooth with some lingering roast in the finish. Not a bad example of the style, but certainly a less malty version that some and the off flavor detracts.

Bottle. Poured a darker brownish, black color with a tan head. Aroma was faint roasted malts, caramel and hops. Flavor was roasty, woody, caramel and hops. Very thin and watery. Not much body to this beer. Just below avarage.

THOUGHTS: Seed like Guinness and a crap light lager had a baby. Turns pretty bad as it warms up. I wish this was sold in four packs instead of six. One of the worst schwarzbiers I’ve tried. 
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown with red highlights and a large, grayish brown head that mostly diminished and left good lacing. The aroma had light to moderate grain and roasted malt; slight caramel; and light to moderate grassy hops; The initial flavor was slightly sweet, lightly sour and lightly bitter; while the finish was lightly sour and light to moderately bitter with an average to long duration. There was slightly caramel, roasted malt, grassy and metallic hops and a little sour malt. The light to medium body was a bit oil and then slightly dry with fizzy carbonation and a metallic finish.

Ruby brown color/ tan sheen. Roasty, dry black malt, stale cigarette smoke, vegetal aromas. Light bodied with avg co2. Nice dry black malt, burnt pecan, chocolate malt ball, roasty nutty flavors--almost good.
Bottle. Pours black with off white head. Nose and taste of roasted black and chocolate malts, light pine and some barley and cereal grains. Medium body.

12oz bottle.  Aromas of barley malts some roasty notes and a bit of chocolate. Flavor is bitter with the usual Guinness taste only watery and malty. Body is dissapointing and finish is quick.  Feels like a Guinness knock off

12oz bottle. Pours a very dark mahogany black with a thin tan head. Bread and hay in then ose, but in all honesty there isn’t much of an aroma. OK mouthfeel, flavor of raost malt, some hops. I think it’s a mindset thing - I expect to taste a stout. Go figure. Overall, a little bit disappointing.
Pours pitch black with a decent tan head and a treacle aroma. There is a modest roasted malt flavor with a rather nasty chalky finish. Guinness needs to fix this one.

10.30.2011 - Houston, TX
Bottle

A light Guinness with less flavor. I would chose something different if I wanted lighter, but if your looking for Guinness just go for the real deal...

Aroma: subtle roast and coffee, very faint.  Pours black, fizzy off-white head dissipates quickly and leaves some thin lacing.  Flavor has some nice chocolate and roast, coffee and earthy notes.  Body is a bit thin, medium carbonation.

Poured into a Lager Glass. Pours really dark brown almost black. Nice frothy head with a little lacing on the glass. aroma is pleasant, roasted malts and almost a citrusy smell too. Flavour is clean and finishes with the roasty notes. Palate is thin and watery, but that’s the point of a lager. Carbonation is lively on the tongue. Overall one of the better Black Lagers I’ve tried.

Pours clear dark brown with nice layer of frothy brown head.  Aroma is corny and bland, slight roasty, but very minimal - stale.  Flavor very dry and burnt.  Pretty watery.  Overall, decent  drink for the fall, but overall lacks the depth I was hoping for.

Pours very dark, with tan head. Very little aroma. Taste of Carmel and a little malt. Smooth enough, but really not that great. Can’t give this one a thumbs up. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

11.2 ounce bottle - Taco Mac in Canton, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a near black body with very dark mahogany-hued hints at the edge and topped with a small-sized, off-white head.

Smell: Ultra faint hint of roast. And...well... There’s just not much at all to it.

Taste: Pale malted barley, maybe even a trifling inclusion of pils malt. Very, very low roastiness, more like they added caramel coloring to achieve the color. Faintly herbal hint of hops with a minute bitterness. More of the same (which isn’t much) until the crispish finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-light body. Medium carbonation. Reasonably crisp.

Overall: As bland, boring, and deficient as their flagship beer but without the treasured history of the standard Guinness Stout.

bottle poured into tulip. Thick short lived tan head, fair lacing, dark coffee/red. smell, black pepper, ashes without smokey-ness, almost invisible caramel malt smell very late, a touch of oregano? Taste ashes and soap. Small bubble carbonation, hops arrive after a brief resting period then stick to middle tongue. Overall, this is a weird, incomplete beer. It is a rougher yet thinner version of Koestritezer’s Schwartzbier.

Suggestion, I blended this beer with a homebrew barley wine (11.71abv) and an O’Douls Amber (near beer/non-alcohol)...and it  was delicious.
Pours black smells like coffee grounds and compost. Tastes like burnt toast. Sucks!
Funny, its like a lagered version of the stout. Thin, roasty and insipid, with a plain finish. Light, nearly watery palate. Bleh.

33 cL bottle at Sunset Grill. Pours dark brown to black with a creamy, tan and semi lasting head. Aroma is roasted malty and light breadish, mild cornish too. Cornish, toasted malty and dark breadish. Light metallic and bitter flavoured. Dark roasted and dry finish.

Bottle. Deep brown approaching black. Frothy, off-white head, rapidly diminishing. Light aroma of similar to a pale lager but with a hint of roast, but only a hint. Toasted grain, earthiness. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and lightly bitter. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. "Guinness" taste in the finish. But light on the roast for a schwarzbier. Easy drinking, but thin. No wonder Guinness suggests drinking it very cold.
Bottle.  Mild malt aroma, medium body, ligh all around, mild carbonation, finish is caramel malt.  No problems with this one, is refreshing but with some taste.  Fits a purpose.

Pours black with a slight creamy tan head. Odor is light citrus followed by very dark malt. Med minus body. Flavor is thin dark malt. It is bitter. However, this is not a substantial beer. But it is rather flavorful.

Smells like a lager brewed cold with some roasted barley notes.  Head dissipated quickly.  Color is pitch black.  Mouthfeel is slightly more than light.  Taste is of roasted barley, corn/rice notes of your typical lager.  Carbonation taste kills this one pretty quickly.  Had slightly higher hopes on this one since the labeling is so crafty.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Very light coffee roasty aroma with some light earthy notes. The flavor has lightly roasted malts, light bittersweet chocolate, toasted grains, and light palate.

Appearance: medium-dark brown, lightish highlights, a one-finger light tan head that was surprisingly long-lived.   Aroma: a little chocolate, a whisper of roast coffee, and a bit of grassy hops.   Taste:  weak--toasty, with notes of chocolate, roasted malts, and a bit of black pepper.   Finish: smooth, short, a wee bit toasty.   Notes: It’s essentially a black and tan, but instead of porter and lager, it’s half a guinness with a bud ice.  All this did was make me want a Guinness Extra Stout.  In its defense, the palate was almost perfect.

Bottle.  Pours clear black with a small, fizzy off-white head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is roast and chocolate malt, leather yeast, earthy notes, and dark fruits.  Flavor is medium malt, light hops, leather yeast, and a clean lager character.  Light body, low warmth, medium carbonation.
12oz bottle, thanks BeerandBlues2.  Cola-black body topped by beige head. Aroma is medium sweet, roast, light burnt.  Taste is medium sweet, roast, light burnt.  Light-medium body, lightly watery.

Dark brown with brown lowlights and a creamy beige topper.  Aroma is pretty bland with roasted malt and weak chocolate.  Taste is non descript with mild roasted malts, a hint of chocolate and not much else.  Seven years ago I might have liked this but today it’s just another gateway beer click on here.

Not a very impressive offering from the good folks at Guinness.  The beer pours a very dark color, just about black.  The head is tan with no lacing at all.  The aroma features some roasted barley with a very light hint of vanilla and cream.  The body is rather light and slightly bland, with the roasted barley coming on the strongest.  The carbonation is fairly high, almost cola-like, and the finish is a bit on the sweet side.
Poured ann opauque black with a closer to white head. Nose of burnt malt and flavours of said malt, but lacking any depth.
Pours black with brown around edges.  Armoa is light malts.  Taste of malts and hard chocolate candy.  Maybe some root beer flavor.  The backend is alittle unpleasant.

(Bottle from Candia Road Convenience) Pours very dark brown, almost black but with some brown highlights. Aroma is weakly dry chocolate and roast with something a bit off. Mouthfeel medium-full, a bit dryish and prickly. Flavor of weak chocolate or cocoa with perhaps nut. Kind of an off/sour undertone. Mass-produced, weak feel. Can pass on this one.

Pours black with virtually no head. Nose is light and generic weak lager with a pinch of roastiness and skunk. Flavor has a bit of old hops, weak coffee, and herb but is generally limp. Cereal-like finish, but also very weak here as well. This is a boring, cheap black lager. Stick to Irish Drys, Guinness.

I was hoping that this beer was going to be the 250 anniversary stout just rebottled and with a different label. I really enjoyed that beer and it got some really good ratings. So i had my hopes up. Sadly, this beer is not that. That being said, it’s still a pretty tasty brew and a nice change of pace from a regular Guinness. Worth a try, lighter than a guinness and with more carbonation. It is definitely not a stout but a lager for sure. Not bad, I’d drink it again.

Guinness Black Lager is a black beer with a waxy, turbanado colored foam that has pretty nice lacing and retention.  The aroma is very muted and of wet cardboard.  There’s a touch of roast and maybe spice in the nose.  It’s medium-light bodied; fluffy and crisp.  It’s lightly flavored from a dark malt twang at the first taste to a lightly bitter finish of coffee and medicine.  This stuff just goes down like water.  It’s a very simple, refreshing black lager.

Was really expecting more from the guys at Guinness.  This beer pours a deep black with nice foam, but the flavor is totally lacking.  A little bit of roasted taste and some butterscotch, but otherwise quite thin.  I was expecting Guinness quality and got all show and no substance.  Send it back to Malaysia for further testing.

Ummm...was expecting this to be a good brew....not so much.  Pours a nice black color with a small head.  Nothing noteworthy other than being just an ordinary dark beer.  Would I ever order this again...probably not.

Bottle. Pours out a rootbeer brown with a bubbly off white head, this actually no joke looks like pouring out an IBC or Stewart’s rootbeer. Aroma is of light roast ans some chocolate with malt sweetness. Body is slightly watery, some burnt grains, light caramel, little chocolate. Its like having a less full bodied black and tan.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours almost opaque mohogany with a medium beige head with decent retention; leaves some creamy lace. Aroma is pretty muted but a little bread shows through. Taste is bittersweet with a dry and somewhat salty finish. Has a wet river rock/mineral flavor in the finish. Crisp and refreshing. Average carbonation. It could be more roasty, but I like it.

bottled pours black with large tan head. aromas of basement, hay and tin. flavors are of malt. the beer is medium sour with a little bitterness from the roasting. medium to light body, with a thin bitter/astringent tongue feel. this lasts for a while on the palate, which is really not pleasing. they should have stayed with what they do best.
Drank straight from bottle. Dark and smooth. Smooth malt flavors with a slight bitter after taste.

Not bad, but certainly nothing special... Beautiful BLACK, non-transparent color with a light muddy colored head.  Malty, but light and thin.  Pretty typical for the style I suppose, but I have had better Schwarzbier.

From my beer friend nike, BIG THANKS!  This is a nice looking beer out of tghe bottle.  Nice rocky head.  Smell is clean and crisp with a tad of roastyness in there. A nicely flavored easy to drink beer.  Has some of that slaggy flavor in there. Some bitterness tries to build but it never quite gets there. Mild for the most part and at 4.5% it goes down rather easy. Enjoyable beer experience. Not as strong or personified as many schwartz but it gets close, yet more flavor than a dark lager.  Most guinness is fun to take and so is this, not bad overall!  Thanks B!

Bottle- Pours a black color with a nice tan head that fades to good lacing. Very muted aroma of roasted malt and bit of caramel sweetness. Starts with a mild bitterness witha trace of roasted malt, not much else and a dry finish. Fairly medium body, quite smooth but no character. A non-discript offering from Guinness. I guess it’s for people who want to be hip but do not like stouts.

11.2 ounce bottle.  Pours black with a slight red hue and a nice two inch tan head that slowly fades.  Taste is of roasted malt, smoke, grass, hops and Guinness.  Has a decent, carbonated body.  Similar aroma.  Easy to drink and rather enjoyable.  Would be worth having again, if the price wasn’t so high.

11.2 oz. bottle - Pours a clear brown color with a one finger thick light tan head.  Very light spotty lacing.  Aroma and flavor is lightly roasted malt, caramel malt, light chocolate, and herbal hops.  Light to medium body.  A decent beer.
Bottle.  Pours almost pure midnight black with a small head.  Light toasted flavor, medium body, smoooth finish.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of hard roasted barley, slight chocolate, and grain.  Poured very dark brown/mahogany in color with a small, creamy, dense, tan head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is slightly sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of hard roasted barley, grain, roasting, and a hint of chocolate.  Medium body.  Thin, then lightly dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Hard roasted barley, roasting, and hint of chocolate in the dry finish.

Pours almost black with a little tannish head. Aroma has some dark roasted, almost burnt smelling malts, and some chocolate lingering in there. Tastes has some chocolate notes and some slight hop bitterness, with a watery mouthfeel afterwards. Rather thin for the most part, but still very drinkable.

Pours black into a pint glass. Mocha head crackles and pancakes as it slowly recedes leaving sheet lacing. Slightly burnt toast aromas. Dry with pumpernickel and chocolate upfront turing slightly sour in the toasty finish.

Black pour with decent head and lacing. Mild aroma with hints of caramel, yeast, and burnt malt. Mild, very drinkable flavor: malt (hint of burnt malt) well balanced by bitterness. Nice body with clean finish. A fine session beer.
Pours a black color with a tan head. Aroma is of light roasted malts with some chocolate and caramel malts. Flavor is slightly watery up front with a roasted finish.
11.2 ounce bottle.  Pours almost black with a small tan head.  Mild aroma of burnt malt and a bit of chocolate.  Taste is very similar.  Decent enough.
Light roasted malt aroma. Very dark amber color with a small brown head. Sweet beginning with a light bitter finish. Lighter palate.

a good change off from my IPAs, both micro brewery ones and my own.
lower ABV, quite refreshing(sounds so commercial) and unexpected from Guinness especially since I consider Guinness Draft the best beer ever made though an IPA lover....no other lager comes close, not even Yuengling Black and tan. OK I GOOFED..BORING AFTER AWHILE GOOD FOR 2 BEERS........

Pours near black with reddish hues and a fully receding tan head. Notes of dark, lightly sweet malt, pronounced hop bitterness, and a brief toffee sweetness with a dry finish. Thin to medium bodied with soft lively carbonation.
Hardly any aroma, tastes like burnt chocolate carbonation.... Very flat beer not too great......

there nothing special about this beer. I can assume that Guinness wanted to try something but it didn’t work the way they wanted. the aroma and the taste are pretty flat with high carbonation. the malts are almost bland with a touch of burnt toast. Give it a try, but dont expect much

Poured from a twelve ounce bottle into a chilled pint glass.  Black lager is a deep black brown opaque liquid with a very generous head of big bubbles.  Nose is faint malt.  Rather innocuous.  Taste is dry malt black coffee bitters on a thin body.  Slight fizzy mouthfeel.  Finishes clean.  No real heft.  Rather like Guinness stout only watered down and half as awesome.

Fresh 11.2 oz. unbottled into a Duvel logo tulip at 2:53:24, Oct. 2, 2011 - approximately 40* Fahrenheit - 4.45* Celsius. Did not "enjoy ice cold straight from the bottle" as per instructions from Artie Guinness himself; because that’s stupid.  Pours a dark brown/black with creamy tannish head that dissipates quickly.  Looks pretty great.  Give it a whiff - very subtle notes of light bready, toasty/roastiness and some slight malt sweetness - super impressed with rather lame smell.  Taste buds say: Light roasty, chocolate malt flavor, slightly bitter malt on the very end.  Mouthfeels: Quite full-bodied for ABV, very light carbonation, smooth - but not slick or oily,  crisp, and fairly dry on the very end.  It’s amazing how Artie can make such a full-bodied and gorgeous-looking beer with such little actual nose and flavor.  It reminds me of another couple of similar beers...  Hmmm... Oooh, rite... Guinness Draft and Guinness Extra Stout.  In a word - BoringTimesBeer.

Deep black body with a rich tan colored head. A nose of peanuts and bread crust up front. There is also some hint of wood smoke. The body is light and lifeless. This tastes a little smoky with hints of coffee and raw soybeans. The finish continues the soybeans with bits of grass. This is a weak effort.

Very bland is the best I can say about this beer. It looks good, dark brown with a tan head. Slightly malty aroma, very mild. The taste is again, bland. Just not a lot going on. The finish is watery. Nothing to recommend.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with a beige head. Very light coffee-ish roasty aroma with some light earthy notes. The flavor has lightly roasted malts, light bittersweet chocolate, toasted grains, and light earthy notes. Pleasant enough.

11.2 fl oz bottle. Nearly pitch black color (some clear brown around the edges of the glass), minimal off-white head. Toasty malty aroma, more wheaty. light bitter coffee taste. Hint of hops. light bitter taste. Carbonation a bit too pronounced. A decent dark lager.

Poured from bottle into standard pint glass. Not sure what "cold-brewed" means, nor why they tell us to drink from the bottle, but this was definitely worth the try. I love Guinness Stout, and I must admit this retains many of my favorite characteristics in a cleaned-up lager version: black color with creamy beige head, malty sweetness, lots of roasted barley dryness, hints of coffee and chocolate in the bitter aftertaste. I wondered if this would taste like a watered-down Guinness Stout, a complex Baltic Porter, or a really neutral black lager. Answer: none of the above. This really is something new and unique. Check it out.

Bottle as shown. Pours a very dark brown with a medium frothy beige head leaving spotty lacing along the glass. The aroma is a bready malt and licorice. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet malt and chocolate with a light bitter finish. A good schwarzbier from Guinness.

Bottle marked: 15:13-L1208GF001. Dark brown pour with an abundance of soft, fluffy cream head and a lot of lacing.  Mellow aroma of roasted malts and barley.  Medium to full bodied on the tongue.  The taste has a notable maltiness but a lower, subtle bitterness to cap it off.  A quick drink.
Pours with a decent almost purplish head. Resonable hop aroma. Very smooth flavor with a full body.
From a bottle poured a black color with a fair amount of head.  Toasted malty flavor with a lingering finish.
Poured almost black with white head.  Tasted like bud light with guinness poured in, which makes it better than bud light, but still not great.

Bottle. Poured a dark clear brown color with an average frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting and produced good lacing. Moderate toasted malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium roasted sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of short duration. Soft drinkable brew.
Date: September 24, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Minneapolis Beer Fest.  Full description not available as I sampled way too many beers in 4.5 hours!

BOttle pour. Inky dark brew that looks a like like a stout, cept for the head being fizzy and not creamy. Light lagerish aroma of grains, adjunt, a little roasted malt. Taste is very lagerish - like a macro lager with minimal roasted malt taste. Thin palate.

25 Sept 2011, bottle. black, doesn’t have to settle like a normal guinness. smells like a handful of toasted malt and burnt coffee. thin and fizzy. there is a black lager taste but it gets a bit tinny in the finish. i’ve had much better black lagers.

Whole Foods, P st, DC sixer ($9): Pours black with a quickly dissipating, kind of funny colored head. Light chocolatey aroma, with some roasted malts. A hint of that typical grainy lager aroma in there as well. Body is actually a little watery kind of like seltzer. But, the tastes that are there are good. Certainly no off taste in there, but not enough taste to really justify this beer’s existence. In any case, I am glad Guinness tries out new things.

There is hope yet for the big boys. Just saw this available in the local market and decided to do a comparison with regular draught. More body, a little more sweetness, and maybe even more bitterness, This is just a better-balanced and more enjoyable beer overall. Smooth roast and grain in the aroma. Just a touch of coffee in the flavor, and plenty of bubbles, which is probably the biggest difference between this and regular draught, The lack of nitro makes a completely different beer. I guess this miht be more of a lighter version of extra stout. Despite my disdain for it, Guinness is still the more fascinating macro to me. I’d like to see this get around.

The aroma is nice but weak with brown sugar, burnt malt, chocolate, honey, and flowers. The appearance is darn brown with a tan head. The taste is a little like the aroma but overshadowed by soapy bitterness and peppers. The palate is smooth. Overall not one of those beers that makes you want another.

pours very dark brown, almost black with small but sustaining off white, beige head.  Aroma of light smoke.  Flavor is lightly charred roast, with a touch of meat smoke, cocoa.  Medium bodied.  Nice but forgettable.

Really dark brown with a medium sized beige head. Aroma of roasted barley, molasses, and nuts. Taste is a touch thin; roasted and malty and ever so slightly bitter. Medium thin. Not bad, but I won’t buy it again.

This poured a nice black color with a beige head. The aroma contains chocolate and a bit of nuttiness. The flavor is rather dry with some chocolate, coffee, and licorice. The palate is a bit thin. Overall not world class but an ok beer.

11.2oz in Drake’s pint glass. Near black with small fizzy ecru head. Very appetizing cornflakes and distant coffee aroma. Clean and tasty flavors of molasses, Munich malt, and sweet corn. Pleasant lager finish, generous carbonation. Excellent sessionable, interesting beer.
I found this pretty tasty. Some roasty notes, not that heavy, certainly hit the spot for Beer Friday at work.
bottle, black color with short lived tan foam, aroma is nutty caramel, flavor of spritz and some roast malt , very plain
What’d they do here, roast up a Harp? I think I actually prefer Sam Adam’s Black Lager to this Thin, boring and flat.

12oz bottle. Poured a dark black color with a small tan head. Aroma was roasted malts, touch of coffee perhaps? Taste was bitter, dark roasted malts. It wasn’t too bad actually, had no idea they made this until I found it in some random mid-west grocery store in August.
Pours dark brown color with light tan head. Toasted malt and caramel aromas. Very bland lightly roasted malt flavor. Light to medium body with moderate carbonating.

12oz bottle from Pick’s poured into an English Pint. Pours a dark black with about 1 finger of frothy tan head. Aroma of black roasted malt and a slight hint of coffee. Taste is lightly bitter and very lightly sour. Slight hint of coffee. Light bodied with a thin yet creamy texture. Lively carbonation and not much of a finish. Overall, not too bad. Nothing I would seek out but I would definitely choose this over any BMC.
Pours a thin, but deep dark brown with a medium beige lacing. Overall one dimensional and very similar to a BMC light beer.
Chocolaty roasty aromas.  Light on the palate.  Slight chocolate flavor with some sweet malts. Very carbonated.  Overall it’s drinkable.

Move over Bud Light.  You have a toasty competitor.  
Nice very dark brown to black pour.  OK toasty aroma.  Not much to this beer.  Disappointed.  Really this is an easily drinkable beer however I expected a much fuller body from the likes of Guinness in a black lager.
Smelled of wet dog.  Taste reminiscent of a Spaten Lager, but dark.  Drain-pour...and I don’t do that very often.

Bought at Sidney’s in Nawlins.. . Pours a deep brown/black .. medium headring, light lacing .. . slick light mouthfeel .. . not getting an awful lot out of the nose or palate- light roast and just a touch of sweet tar.. . no lay-ups .. . wow, a very very simple schwarz- i mean for guinness to make this, quite surprising on  how one dimensional it is, that being said- i really liked and enjoyed it and can see maybe why they went with such a thin beer, like a guinness but not on nitro... . . Oh, don’t worry about it. All the teachers lose their car on their first day.

12 ounce bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a clear deep dark red with a medium sized creamy head. Good head retention. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. The taste is roasted malts, raisin, chocolate. Thin-medium bodied. Decent.

9/19/11. 12oz bottle into a glass (sorry, Guinness). Black pour, dark brown under the light, with a decent khaki head that sticks and laces a teensy bit. Very plain aroma with tannic graininess, a hint of cream, and a dash of sour. Very light flavor as well with tannic graininess, a bit of dark chocolate, and not much else. Very light body... it’s yet another "dark" beer for Guinness to push on the common man so they think they’re drinking the good stuff.
Skunky aroma. Taste is light and crisp with a light maltiness. Finish is weak, but not unpleasant. Slightly toasty, a bit more roasted in the malt than a standard lager. Better than a macro.

black with red tints, spongy beige head. Smells toasty and grain, maybe a little fruity, I guess. Pretty thin bodied, which works here. Flavor is pretty much what the aroma promises - grainy, tossty, and mild fruit flavors. Not bad. What the hell does "cold brewed" mean, anyway?

This brew pours black with some chestnut color around the edges. Medium thin tan head that diminishes steadily to a film. Somewhat roasty aroma with notes of malt and chocolate. Light to medium body with a roasted malt character and flavors of mild hops and chocolate. The finish is short roasty malt. Seems like this beer is being marketed as a "less heavy Guinness" which is amusing. Simply average overall.

Yay, new beer! 330mL bottle.  Pours dark black, thin head.  Aroma of cold coffee, burnt grains.  Thin texture.  Flavor is of bitter burnt character.  Some lagering character, grain, and earth. Very mild.  I don’t see to many people getting into this beer.  Not the fans of Guinness or even the masses of Schwarzbier fans.  Hmmm?
 Purchased at Publix 26, Cumming GA.

When i first heard this on npr, I actually thought this would actually be worse than it is.  Black pour with decent light tan head looks like regular Guinness.  Actually tastes similar but with a weird vegetalness, but good roasty finish.  I’d still drink the regular draft over this, but I’d take this over bmc still any day.

No widget in the bottle, so I’m not sure why they say you should drink it out of the bottle.  Very mild roasted aroma, with a touch of something I can’t quite place.  Pours an opaque black (no ruby highlights, so it is even darker then Guinness), with a thin light tan head.  Not a very complex flavor, a bit of tartness, and a touch of roast.  Mild finish of roast, with a very thin mouthfeel.  I don’t think this will be bringing too many people over to the fact that dark isn’t a flavor.  It’s not bad, and could be an interesting change of pace if it sticks around.
Pretty boring with mild roast bitterness. Somewhat skunky and watery as well. Gave it a shot but regular Guinness is far better.
Dark, reddish, thin head.  Nice roasted notes in the nose, with minor weak coffee.  Roasted palate, a bit nutty.  Decent, not complex, but standard swarz.  Part of make your own 6 at wegs.

From bottle. Roasted, toasted, light acrid grain notes. Bit of caramel and light hops. Dark black clear with thin tan head. Medium light body with high carbonation. Starts roasted and toasted with carbonic acidity. Medium bitter finish with light tang. Roasted sweetness in the after with mild hop bitterness.
Poured black with nice head tasted sweet slight burnt taste very boring and plain I am glad I split this with someone

Pours the darkest of browns with a tan head. Aroma is sweet malt, roast. Flavor is sweet, grainy, lightly earthy, with some roasty notes. Mostly resembles a Euro macro lager which I guess is what it is.

Bottle.  Pours dark, dark brown with a medium light tan head that leaves a ring of lacing.  Aromas of mild chocolate, some caramel, cereal, and those little marshmallows from Lucky Charms.  Very mild flavor, basically like subdued Guinness; light cocoa, some lactose, and roasty malt.  Average.  [796]

What is "cold brewed", anyway?  I have to hand it go Guinness, they managed to brew a beautiful black beer that tastes like Budweiser.  Honestly, why?  Could have had a lot more character.  I wouldn’t call this a Schwarzbeer.  I would call it a "Black American Lager", if that was a category.  If I drank this blindfolded, I would have no clue that it was black.  Really just tastes like Budweiser.  What more is there to say?

Bottle at Fox and Parrot. This is kind of disappointing, really. I was just expecting just a Guinness clone. But this is like Guinness light with some vegetal lager flavors. It lacks the roast of a good schwarzbier or Guinness stout. Meh.

Malty, dunkel aroma, with some cocoa and toast.  Distinctive label, very dark black-brown beer, thin ivory head. Pleasant, toast-and-roast flavor, dry, not very bitter - a good session brew.  Medium to slightly-light body, slightly watery.  Mild roast finish.  Publix, Bradfordville.

Bottle. Not as good as I thought it would be. Tastes more like a average lager than a schwarzbier. Started off good. Nice dark color, nice head. Aroma, smells kind of like metal. Taste, just not that great.

deep brown, small tan head, light lacing, not guinness style.. roasty almost to the point of being burnt aroma, light fruits, thin aroma... lightly roasty, light fruits, toasty, not much hops, lightest grassy... thin light body, a little slick... tastes like an ok american dark lager...

Pours deep brown/black with a large foamy tan head.  Nice lacing and retention.  Aroma is very faint but has a bit of roastiness and a bit of coffee.  Flavor is slightly better...a bit roasty, some spicy hops, and a bit of a metallic note.  Mouthfeel is light and lively with a mildly roasted, mildly dry finish.  Largely unimpressive.

Tallahassee, Fl - Publix Supermarket - 12 oz bottle. Very dark brown pour, light, but persistent khaki colored head - a bit of trailing lacing. Aroma is somewhat neutral, a hint of fresh lake water, very brief chocolate. Flavor has some hints of dark chocolate, a bit of day old coffee, wisps of licorice. Medium thick mouthfeel - par for the style. Decent schwarzbier.
bottle.  pours black with a medium tan head.  nose is light roasted barley.  flavor is mostly lager-like with some ashy, charred notes.  very dry and un-sweet finish.  light body.
Bottle pours a dark brown almost black with a thin off white head. Scent is roasty with corn. Taste is roasty, grainy and earthy. Thin

Pours a very dark brown color, almost black but has a distinct reddish hue when held up do the light. The head is small but fairly well retained. 



The aroma is nice and roasty rich and kind of chocolaty as I pour it from the bottle then whoops; where did it go? I was so happy about that aroma now I can’t find it anywhere? 



The flavor is very clean all around with only mild roasty notes, a little bit of chocolate. What’s there is nice enough, but this is very low in flavor.



The plate is very thin & the finish is very quick.



Well, this one pretty well sets the bar for me as far as totally unremarkable but absolutely unoffensive goes.
Pitch black with a foamy but quickly dissipating tan head. On top of the roasted malts the aroma has a mild woody hint and the flavor is relatively dry an bitter. The blackest lager around. Not bad
Mild roasted maltiness in the aroma while the appearance is darker than most other black lagers.  The flavor is of roasted malts and rather thin in body.  Decent but could have been more flavorful.
Dark brown with amber tint and tan head.  Roasted malt smoky aroma.  Roasted malt flavor some chocolate and smoke.  Thin feel in mouth.
Pour is light brown. no head. smell is roasty. taste is watery and roasted like a not so strong black tea.

Bottle from a sixer poured into a fluted pint glass.  Dark brown pour with a foamy tan head that fizzes away quickly.  Aroma is roasted malt, sweet grain, and lager yeast.  Tastes like Guinness Lite.  I won’t have a problem finishing the other five, but I wouldn’t buy it again.

Curious little bottle attracted my attention when I wasn’t really looking to buy beer. I’ve had a lot of Guinness over the years and while I don’t drink it much anymore it’s still got a special place...
So anyhow this pours a dark brown with ruby highlights and a creamy off white head that quickly dissipates to a cap. No widgets in here to release nitrogen and keep this head stable for an hour. Smells, yup it smells, just like a macro lager. Pilsner malt, grainy, grassy, corny. There’s a faint and I mean faint aroma of roasted grains, but I would imagine most of the color from this thing came from sinamar. Taste follows the smell really well and ends with quite a dry finish. Light body, medium carbonation, thin watery mouthfeel. Maybe this would make a good gateway beer for someone, but for me this one was a let down. Nothing exciting here at all.

bottle at azwine 8/30/11.
it appears to be pretty dark... bordering a dark porter colored blackish brown with a lasting tan head.

there is a sweaty, dusty note in the aroma which reminds me of a bag of oats. also, i can smell, sulfur from the yeast, roasted barley, mild nutty coffee and milk chocolate with some vanillin in it.

more of the same from the flavor only it is rather muted and watered down. the first few sips taste more like the glass than a beer. it is clean on the finish and leaves an aftertaste of roasted barley. the mouth feel is slick airy and soft at first. something happens to it as it sits because it ends up watery. so, the moral of that story is to chug it!

there is nothing special about this. it tastes a lot like a guinness light would taste. it is not bad, just mediocre. 6/4/5/2.5/13/3

If you have had Guinness or Harp then you already know what you are getting here.  Anyone expecting more will come away unimpressed.  This is a light, carbonated lager with roasted malt.  Is it a world beater, no.  But if this was the low bar of beer then it would be 75% better than our current low bar.  Pours a nice brown/black with a sparkly tan head.  Watery and light with roasted notes and sparkling soda in minor amounts.
Pour cola brown with no head.  Cream-colored rim.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and some earthiness.  Body is a bit light and watery.  Not a great beer, but not bad either.

Ar: Light malt, a bit of moss, and coffee.
Ap: Very dark brown, red highlights - medium light tan head with big bubbles - moderate retention.
T: Roast and a touch of coffee up front - some earthiness with light bitterness - quick, ashy finish.
P: Light bodied with medium-high carbonation - falls a bit thin on the palate.
O: Decent black lager - nothing special, pretty underwhelming.

Blah. The only good thing about this beer is the aroma. The aroma was a thick dense roasted coffee. Pour was a nice enough dark brown with some rising bubbles and a one finger tan head. Taste was very thin and watery. There’s literally no flavor upon first sip. The strong carbonation numbs the cheeks and gums. After the swallow the mouth is left with some coffee and dark roasted malt flavors. Very bland and boring
Bottle, pours opaque black w/ foamy off-white head, aroma is even mix of roasted malt, adjunct, and dishwater, thin and watery w/ only the lightest roast accent on finish, unimpressive

11.2 ounce bottle.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours black with about an inch tan head that went away quickly.  There’s a decent amount of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, and some bittersweet chocolate.  Taste is similar to the aroma, but there’s also a slight nutty flavor.  Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, it’s pretty easy to drink and is well carbonated.  Overall it’s not bad, it’s probably not going to impress you but I think it’s a nice sessionable brew.  I’d buy it again, it’s a decent choice for a lower alcohol brew to end the night with.
Bottle.  I’m not sure what Guinness was getting at with this.  It reminds me of  Harp lager, with a tiny bit of roast malt. Weak finish weak aroma.  Commonplace. I can’t recommend this.

I hated this beer. It tasted like Bud Light, but was black. You don’t even taste the roasted malt which gives it the color. It’s simply a boring American light lager dressed up with black malt to make it look more appealing. Awful beer.

The pour made a thick brown head with a with a toasty coffee aroma.  The palate seemed somewhat weak and the flavor was more toast, coffee, and a little bit of chocolate.  Overall a decent black lager, but not outstanding.
I’m glad to see more Guinness selections appearing on the market, but I wish they would make the Guinness 250 recipe a permanent selection, or at least a seasonal one.

Pour is a black with a quickly falling tan head.  Aroma is a ok hint of chocolate and toasted malts.  Flavor is weak and watery and the taste of dark malt does not come to the table until after the swallow.  I’m sure Guinness makes plenty of money from their stout so I don’t know why they put this out.

bottle. dark schwarzbier/cola looking pour. light roasty aroma, sort of spritzy. Flavor was watered down roasted maltiness, light sweetness. Blah blah, Can’y imagine the $$$$$ that they sunk into this b.s.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark brown with nice tan head. Aroma has light notes of dark roast, cocoa, with that classic Guinness aroma. Flavor is much the same and dry with a mild hop finish. Light body with high carbonation. Overall, taste like a Heineken with dark roasted flavor and color added.
Dark brown almost black with a cream head.  Nose is roasted malts, ash, caramel, more roast.  easy on the palate, roast, malts, faintly water.
