Comes off as carbonated Guinness to me at first. If Guinness was a lager this is what it would taste like. Its got carbonation now, its a little less roasty, but its still got the milky creamy easy to drink goodness of guinness. I like it and I could drink it heavily all night without a problem I think. But it is pretty overpriced for what it is..Kinda like Guinness.

Bottle:  Pours a dark ruby with a thin off-white head, light grains in the aroma with a hint of chocolate, starts and ends very lightly bitter, thin bodied, subtle carbonation.  It’s a bit sad that Guinness thinks it needs to make a lighter version of their stout which is lighter than most beers.

TPSA. Pours medium brown with a cream ring. Nose is nutty and roasty; it smells promising. Then -- then the wheels come off. It tastes like stale corn tortilla chips dusted with bad freeze-dried coffee. No, no, no, no, and no. Finish is tight and unpleasant.

Pours a dark clear brown with a tall frothy beige head that has great retention. Aroma is toast, cereal grain, grassy, spicy and floral hops, a little honey and some light nutty notes. No real roasty character despite the appearance. Flavor is lightly sweet cereal grain, thick crust white bread, light grassy and floral hops. Palate is light bodied and fairly neutral up until the off dry finish. Think of it as a Schwarzbier Light, or Black Helles (actually that one sounds kinda cool, on paper), as it doesn’t really have any of the roasted malt traits present in any Schwarzbier and has a really low abv for the style.

Bottle.  Pours black.  Light tan head with good retention.  Some lacing.  Very mild roasted malt aroma.  Just the slightest amount of bitterness.  Overall very smooth and clean.  Almost no mouthfeel.  Extremely drinkable.  Decent drinking beer, but nothing that wows you.

Sample from a 12 oz bottle at the Jacksonville Craft Beer Festival, 5-20-2011.  Not distributed in Florida yet, but should be by September according to the company rep.  Its an ok schwarzbier, but nothing exciting.  Very sessionable, almost a light beer at only 4.5%   Sort of a dark malt pilsener with very little of what makes Guinness notable.  Disappointing.
Definitely black but doesn’t resemble many ’dark beer’ flavours. Easy drinking lager that is actually pretty good

This is indeed black, or almost, with a funky brown head that soon leaves blotches and some lacing.  The nose is molasses and that is also noted in the flavor.  Citrus fruit and light cocoa, too.  Feel is light but with some fizz.  A nice beer and an interesting one.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown with a small light tan head. Aroma is sharp roasted malts, touches of dark fruit, bits of chocolate and toast. Flavor starts with some of that dark fruit and sharp roast with a pale lager graininess that comes forth that is quite off putting as it really pushes out the subtleties of the roast and chocolate that were already quite fragile to begin with. Finishes bland, a touch bitter and roasty along with the grain. Light to medium body and a sharp carbonation. Bleh, not very good at all.

11.2 oz. bottle from beer buddy, Brian. Poured to a czech-pils glass with a darkest brown color and ruby highlighting, thick, lasting, deep tan, bubbles and cream head foam, with waves and spots of clingy lacing. The aroma was a typical lager nose, Munich and Pils-like, mild roastiness, and a little cocoa & light grain. The flavor was clean, adding some moderate hop bitterness, no real sweetness, and some light creaminess to the mouthfeel. The body was less than medium, and the finish was subtly dry. Not a bad Schwarz at all, and reasonably sessionable.

Poured from bottle, pours a brownish red with a thin head, aroma was of light malt and the flavor was much of the same with a slight chocolate touch in the finish, mouthfeel is watery but isn’t terrible.

Pours a very dark ruby red with a light brown head.The aroma reminded me of a skuny pilsener.The flavor if you could call it that was a watered down sweet malt.The body was thin with little aftertaste.Overall I could drink it if offered but would not buy it again.
A deep black pour with a tan head.  It has a roasted malt aroma with slight chocolate.  The taste is lightly sweet with an oily texture, lively carbonation, and a roasted finish.
Awful. Over carbonated, and just too sweet. It has none of those typical dark roasted coffee and chocolate flavors that Guinness has, it’s more like a dark version of miller lite.
Bottle.  Clear brownish pour, fizzy off-white head.  Light roasted malt, bad lager malt, slightly skunky, and a bit of sweetness.  Overall this was very boring, about what I expected.

12oz bottle 1/4/11 (Binny’s Plainfield)-48° in Lager Glass-Pours black with a small loose tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and smoke. Taste of the same up front and in the middle but finishes like a pale lager. This light to medium bodied brew is not bad and would fill the void in a pinch.

Purchased at the "green" Jewel in Chicago, IL as part of a mix & match sampler, enjoyed on Boxing Day (12/26) while watching Bears football.  Aroma not really existent, malt if anything, also a bit of lactose but that’s stretching it.  Appearance is like Coca Cola, pure black with a carbonated white head.  Taste also a bit faint, hints of chocolate malt, noticeably carbonated, not bad at all, especially with the mass produced tag of "Guinness".  Would probably drink if I was at a bar with limited options.
Opaque black with a medium tan head.  Roast nose.   Slighly sweet with roast and chocolate flavour.  Thin, watery finish.

In the glass the body is blackest brown, cola in the shallows and shimmering when held up to the light. What goes up sadly came down the head rose on the pour to die back quickly to an island of tight tannish bubbles. Dry nose reminiscent of seaweed, black patent malt and damp, rusty nails, quite tannic. Smoky and very husky black patent malt at first dominates before hints of raw sugar and molasses add a sweetness to the otherwise dry palate. Finish is dry, malty and smoky with a malt bitterness that is pleasing. Body is light, the carbonation quite prickly and throughout adding crispness to the swallow. Easily knock a few of these back in quick succession, as long as they are chilled as the sweetness builds when it warms to become clammy. Not bad as far as a Guinness goes!! (33cL, BB 16/05/11, Thirsty Camel, Butler)
Really good Dark Lager. Taste is very unique, just like traditional Guinness. Will be a new personal preference in times of trouble.
12oz bottle. Jet black body under a small, frothy tan head. Smoke, caramel malt, roasted nuts, chocolate aroma. Medium body, watery. Flavor was slightly sweet but otherwise unremarkable.
Black pour with brown head. Aroma of roasted malt. Roasted malt taste, little light though. Light roasted malt aftertaste.

When I first saw it at the store, I thought Huh! Could be; why not? Although Guinness is in trouble and desperation can lead to weird things. Then I saw the ratings here and was kind of deflated. Then, I poured a huge, tan, foamy, frothy, sudsy head that lasts a while and lots of lace. The color is an opaque black brown. Aroma was very nice with toasty, malt, and toffee. Flavor it falls down: like the nose but much lighter. Body is very light and the force carbonation doesn’t help. Finish is like flavor and short. Schwartzbier with all the calories and a touch of the flavor.

12oz bottle.  Okay, this isn’t really bad in any way.  It’s actually really refreshing and easy drinking.  Pours a smooth very dark red near black, thinner with soda bubbles and a fizzy off-white head.  Light aroma of dark roast, just a smidgen of butter, light kiss of English hops, nicely balanced.  Flavor follows, agree with Oakes: schwarzbier-lite, but it totally works, flavor follows aroma exactly, little bit of a metallic twang either from the water roast or hops, or all three, the hops seem nice and fresh surprisingly, clean too, light bitterness.  This is like a diet-schwarzbier but it totally drinkable, lively crisp carbonation, very clean.

This beer looks like Guinness and tastes like Budweiser. The marketing people said it was the best of all worlds so we made it. We here at Guinness have been pretending to bring you Ireland’s finest beers for quite a while now and we thought this mostly flavorless dark lager was a great way to continue doing so. This fizzling, mass produced beer is brewed using the most modern traditional methods and just enough roasted barley to make it look different while affecting the flavor in no way whatsoever. Cheers!



--Actual St. James’s Gate Literature on Guinness Black Lager
Black body with light tan head. Light roasted notes in the aroma with much the same in the taste perhaps a little grainy, light in body but drinks easy.

Pitch black body with a thin, fizzy head.  Bittersweet cocolate, coffee, and malt make up the rather light aroma.  Nice smooth palate with bright carbonation.  The flavor is overall fairly sweet.  Malt, bitter chocolate, and tobacco.  There’s an interesting aftertaste like you just took a pull off a cigar.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  Schwarzbier is one of my favorite styles, and this one is a good example.
Pours espresso black with thick creamy tan head, nose is slightly roasty, taste is creamy, roasty, mildly bitter, highly drinkable.

Bottle at Belfast Airport. Pours a almost totally black color with a medium beige head. A light sweet caramel, toasted malt and light smooth nutty notes. The flavor is very much a Guinness product; smooth roasted malts, some hints of metal, caramel. Enjoyable.
Bottle from Valley Farm. Lightly roasty nose. Some grains in there as well. Pretty weak aroma. Light roasted flavors. Fairly watery. Bland finish. Not much going on here.

Bottle from the Orland Park, IL, Binny’s:  This pours an intensely dark brown, clear mahogany around the edges, with a bubbly ecru head.  The aroma is dark, lightly roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, and tobacco smoke.  The flavor is the same, but a bit lighter than the nose promised.  Not bad.
An interesting addition to the brand’s portfolio. Most probably aimed at the younger market, judging by the ease of swigging. Taste is very similar to Guinness original.
330ml bottle introductory sale at the Crown Liquor Saloon in Belfast, Northern Ireland 5/9/10. Very good!

Bottle, KL.  Dark chestnut colour.  Thin head.  The aroma is thin, chocolatey-cookiesh (think Oreo with less sugar) with vague nuances of earthiness/mushrooms.  Light body.  Not of a lot of character.   It’s clean, with some rather vague roasty/chocolatey notes.  Thin finish.  Drinks very easy.  Fairly inoffensive beer that stylistically probably slots in as a very light schwarzbier.

Bottle. As Guinness Premium, Malaysia. Opaque black-brown with light inconsequential tan head. Straightforward malty aroma is pure grain, bran cereal, slight husk and molasses but not sweet or muffiny. Mild carbonation. Light on the palate. Thin finish but the flavors do not evaporate. The fresh flavors match the aromas of unadulterated and pure dark malts. The flavors and aromas are clean if a bit on the husky, cereal side. Its main fault is being thin. Immature beer but a nice addition to the Guinness portfolio. I could have more than one.
